headline: Unum Group, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly want to thank all of you for taking the time for joining us this morning.   As always, we’re all available if there’s any further questions that people have over the course of the next several days.   Again, we look forward to hopefully
componenttext:
We certainly want to thank all of you for taking the time for joining us this morning.   As always, we’re all available if there’s any further questions that people have over the course of the next several days.   
Again, we look forward to hopefully seeing many of you at our Investor Day Meeting in New York in November.   
I think, Operator, at this point, that will conclude our Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Call.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Unum Group third quarter 2010 earnings results conference call. This call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Senior Vice President of Investor Relation
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Unum Group third quarter 2010 earnings results conference call. This call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tom White. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Tim. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Unum’s third quarter 2010 analyst and investor conference call. Our remarks this morning will include forward-looking statements, which are statements that are not of current or historical fa
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Tim. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Unum’s third quarter 2010 analyst and investor conference call. Our remarks this morning will include forward-looking statements, which are statements that are not of current or historical fact. As a result, actual results might differ materially from results suggested by these forward-looking statements.
Information concerning factors that could cause results to differ appears in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission and are also located in the sections titled ‘Cautionary Statement Regarding Forward-Looking Statements’ and ‘Risk Factors’ in our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2009, and also in any subsequently filed Forms 10-Q. Our SEC filings can be found in the Investors section of our Web site at www.unum.com.
Please also note that statements in today’s call speak only as of the date they are made, and we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements.
A presentation of the most directly comparable GAAP measures and reconciliations of any non-GAAP financial measures included in today’s presentation can be found on the Web site in the Investors section.
Participating in this morning’s conference call are Rick McKenney, Executive Vice President and CFO; and our business segment Presidents, Kevin McCarthy, Randy Horn, and Jack McGarry.
Now, I’d like to turn the call over to Unum’s President and CEO, Tom Watjen. Tom?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom and good morning. We had another solid quarter with operating income growth for the quarter and year-to-date remaining in line with our 2010 outlook of growth of between 4% and 6%.I would say too that we certainly benefited from our more
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom and good morning. We had another solid quarter with operating income growth for the quarter and year-to-date remaining in line with our 2010 outlook of growth of between 4% and 6%.
I would say too that we certainly benefited from our more diverse business mix as the relatively strong performance of Unum U.S. and Colonial operations driven frankly generally by stable risk trends offset the relatively weaker performance of our Unum U.K. operation.
While the economic and competitive environment in both the U.S. and U.K. remain a challenge, by staying disciplined we have continued to generate solid profitability including strong statutory earnings, which has enabled us to continue repurchase stock while still maintaining a strong capital position.
Now, let me just touch on just a few highlights from the quarter. First, as I indicated, third quarter after-tax operating income grew 3.9%, earnings per share grew 6.5% which are both consistent with our 2010 outlook of growth between 4% and 6%.
Second, while we saw very little change in the business and economic environment this quarter and no substantive changes in the competitive environment, we are capitalizing on profitable growth opportunities as they arise.
I point especially to our voluntary benefits businesses in both Unum U.S. where their sales grew 27% in the third quarter and Colonial where our commercial sales grew 5.7% are good indications of how we’re actually capitalizing on today’s market conditions.
Don’t get me wrong. The combination of the economy and aggressive competitors make it challenging to profitably grow the business, but we feel very good about our market position.
Third, our investment portfolio remains in excellent shape with the net unrealized gain in our fixed maturities securities portfolio increasing as a result of the decline in interest rates and ongoing tightening of credits spreads to $5.7 billion this quarter. The flipside, however, is that today’s low level of interest rate and investment yield can create some challenges, but we have positioned the company to effectively manage through this environment.
Finally, with our solid financial results and strong investment performance, we continue to build on our very strong capital position. Our weighted average risk-based capital ratio is currently at 410% and holding company’s cash and marketable securities position is slightly above $1 billion, giving us continued financial flexibility in these uncertain times. We have built these strong capital levels while also purchasing $198 million of stock during the third quarter and $328 million of stock year-to-date.
In summary, I feel very good about our results so far this year. I think the diversity of our company is becoming more apparent. The relatively strong performance of Unum U.S. and Colonial Life operations offset the lower level of performance in the U.K.
As you know, we made a management change there. I’m confident that under Jack McGarry’s leadership we can more effectively operate in this difficult market environment and capitalize on the growth opportunities, which I believe exist in this market.
While we continue to face premium growth challenges in certain lines of business, we continue to benefit from our disciplined business approach which has allowed us to generate capital that can be used to repurchase stock at a very opportune time.
Now, I’ll ask Tom White to provide an overview on our operating results this quarter. Tom?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Net income for the third quarter was $220.8 million or $0.68 per diluted common share compared to net income of $221.1 million or $0.66 per diluted common share last year. Included in the results of third quarter of 2010, our net realized aft
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Net income for the third quarter was $220.8 million or $0.68 per diluted common share compared to net income of $221.1 million or $0.66 per diluted common share last year. Included in the results of third quarter of 2010, our net realized after-tax investment gains of $0.9 million or less than $0.01 per diluted common share compared to net realized after-tax gains of $9.5 million or $0.02 per diluted common share in the third quarter of 2009.
Net realized after-tax investment gains for the third quarter of 2010 include an after-tax gain of $1.1 million resulting from changes in the fair value of an embedded derivative and a modified coinsurance contract compared to an after-tax gain of $28.9 million in the third quarter of 2009.
Also included in net realized after-tax investment gains for the third quarter are net realized after-tax investment losses of $200,000 related to sales and write-downs of investments, compared to net after-tax losses of $19.4 million in the third quarter of 2009.
Excluding these items, after-tax operating income was $219.9 million for this quarter or $0.68 per diluted common share, compared to $211.6 million or $0.64 per diluted common share in the year ago quarter.
Turning to the operating segments, in total, Unum U.S. operating income increased 4% to $204.7 million in the third quarter. Within Unum U.S., the group disability line reported another solid quarter with income up 4% to $77.8 million, driven primarily by improved risk experienced on a year-over-year basis.
Within the group life and AD&D line, operating income increased 6% to $52.8 million in the third quarter, a slight improvement in premium income as well as stable risk experience helped to generate the improved earnings.
In the supplemental and voluntary line, third quarter income was up 2.8% to $74.1 million from $72.1 million a year ago. The improvement was driven by strong earnings growth from the voluntary benefits line of business.
Moving to Unum U.K., operating income in this segment decreased $19.6 million to $47.2 million. Operating income declined 15.1% in local currency. While, premium income in local currency was essentially flat in the third quarter. The benefit ratio of 66.9% was well above the unusually low benefit ratio of the year ago quarter.
You’ll recall that the third quarter of 2009 benefit ratio benefited from a reserve reduction associated with the significant reduction in the value of inflation index-linked policies.
This reduction in reserves was largely offset by a corresponding reduction in net investment income on index-linked securities. The year-over-year reduction in income reflects pressure from the economic environment on our ability to resolve claims and continued competitive pricing pressures, particularly in the group disability line.
Concluding our core operations Colonial Life had a strong quarter with premium growth of 6.2% and operating income growth of 5.8% compared to last year. The benefit ratio was 49.9% this quarter compared with the year ago benefit ratio of 48.2% been in line with our longer term expectations for this business segment.
The Individual Disability - Closed Block operating income was $9.8 million compared to $7.2 million in the year ago quarter. The interest adjusted loss ratio was higher at 85.5% this quarter compared to 81.6% in the year ago quarter, but was consistent with the second quarter of 2010. Premium income declined by 6% and net investment income was up 1% year-over-year.
Finally, the Corporate and Other segment reported an operating loss of $10.8 million compared to a loss of $13.7 million in the year ago quarter. Net investment income was higher reflecting higher levels of invested assets and higher miscellaneous net investment income while interest expense increased to $31.8 million this year compared to $24.1 million last year, reflecting the debt issuances from September of 2009 and September of 2010.
So with that review of our operating results, I’ll turn the call over to Rick McKenney for a deeper analysis of this quarter’s results.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. In my comments I’d like to discuss this quarter’s key drivers which have remained relatively consistent and also cover our investment portfolio, interest rate management and our capital position.First, starting on how risk is perform
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. In my comments I’d like to discuss this quarter’s key drivers which have remained relatively consistent and also cover our investment portfolio, interest rate management and our capital position.
First, starting on how risk is performing, across the company, it is generally stable with some pockets of elevated experience off of last year’s very favorable results. Focusing on Unum U.S., risk experience remained generally stable across all lines this quarter.
Our group disability results remained strong with the third quarter benefit ratio of 84.6%, lower than the year ago quarter experience of 85.3% due to more favorable claim recovery performance and flat with the benefit ratio in the second quarter.
New claim incidents for the quarter was consistent with the year ago experience, but slightly elevated relative to the second quarter. The claim incidents trends are not showing notable underlying trends or any signs of being economically influenced.
This quarter’s results also reflect our view that our group disability benefit ratio will level out this year and that longer-term opportunities for improvement can be achieved gradually as our core market exposure changes with our in-force mix of business.
I would note that given today’s challenging environment, I believe our current pre-tax margin of 15% and ROE of 12.6% for the third quarter for the group disability business line are quite strong.
Also, within Unum U.S., group life and AD&D experience remained very steady with the third quarter benefit ratio at 70.4% compared to 70.3% in the year ago quarter and second quarter as well.
Finally, the voluntary and supplemental lines showed favorable claims experience in the voluntary benefit line with third quarter benefit ratio declining to 54.6% from 59% a year ago, offset by a slightly higher benefit ratio in the individual disability recently issued lines due to higher average size of new claims.
The long-term care lines showed generally steady interest-adjusted loss ratios of 80.9% in the third quarter compared to 80.8% in the second quarter and up from 77.5% in the year ago quarter.
Moving to our Unum U.K. results, risk results were worse than last year and up slightly sequentially, with the third quarter 2010 benefits ratio at 66.9%. Weaker results have a number of drivers including lower net claim resolutions and continued competitive pricing pressures in the group disability line which is only partially offset by a slight improvement in group life experience.
The impact of inflation on the inflation index-linked group policies is generally a non-economic influence and was a significant contributor to the year ago year-over-year change in the benefit ratio, but had minimal impact on the sequential quarter results.
The competitive market conditions are negatively impacting our margins in the U.K. and we expect this drive to continue for the near term. I’ll remind you that the Unum U.K. pre-tax margin was 29% and ROE was nearly 21% this quarter, still a very healthy level of profitability.
Finally, Colonial Life risk result this quarter was somewhat unfavorable in the accident, sickness and disability line of business and drove the benefit ratio for the quarter to just under 50% compared to 48.2% in the year ago quarter. As we had mentioned before, we believe that the benefit ratio of around 50% is likely an ongoing expectation for Colonial Life, as a whole.
Turning to the premium line, the challenges continue in today’s economic and business environment. Looking at Unum U.S. first, we are not seeing any improvement in the natural growth that we have discussed with you over the past several quarters.
Our estimate is that natural growth still represents a stubborn headwind of approximately 1% today as the economy and specifically high unemployment and low wage inflation continue to pressure our top line.
The highlight we continue to see within Unum U.S. is our success in growing our voluntary benefits business. Sales in this line increased 27% to third quarter and are now up 17% year-to-date. Having a strong voluntary benefits presence is essential to our strategy as we believe our markets will move towards more employ participation and benefit plans and our team is executing very well in this area of growth.
Within Unum U.K. we are starting to see some stabilization of our premium income, however we continue to expect to see pressure over the near term as competitive market conditions persist and economic trends remain challenging in the U.K.
Our new sales were somewhat encouraging this quarter, and while they were down 3% in local currency this quarter, the comparison was very difficult given the success we had in the second half of 2009 gaining sale as competitor was exiting the market.
In addition we are continuing to see a greater portion of our sales mix from group disability relative to group life, which is more in line with the balance that we’re looking for.
Rounding now with Colonial Life result, our growth metrics remain in good shape. Third quarter sales increased by 2.3%, less than the rate of growth we experienced in the first half of the year as public sector sales were down on a year-over-year basis, but the commercial markets results remain good with third quarter sales growth of 5.7%.
Recruiting trends continue to be strong with new contracts up 14.2% this quarter and up 19.6% year-to-date. New account growth also remains encouraging up 10.2% this quarter and 17% for year-to-date.
Chattering these positive results, our average new case size is lower by 8.8% driven by the economy and the tendency for our newer agents to have their initial success in the smaller end of the market.
With positive sales and recruiting momentum along with stable persistency trends Colonial Life’s premium grew 6.2% for the third quarter. As we shifted the balance sheet our investment portfolio continues to be a highlight as we continue to see excellent results in the credit profile of our portfolio.
With the rally in the treasury markets during the third quarter, our net unrealized gain position for our fixed maturities securities portfolio improved further to a quarter-end level of $5.1 billion compared to a gain of $3.7 billion at June 30.
Net realized investment losses this quarter were insignificant. Importantly, our internal watchlist of potential credit problems in the investment portfolio continues to decline to deploy where in aggregate they sit in an unrealized loss position of less than $5 million.
As happy as we are about the strong credit profile the downside of low interest rates and tight corporate bond spreads is obviously the challenge it creates for new money investment opportunities.
As we have discussed it in the past the key focus for our business in this environment is relationship between the portfolio yields back in various product lines and the aggregate discount rates embedded in the reserves.
For the third quarter, our portfolio yields held up very well with our aggregate portfolio yield of 6.73%, down only 3 basis points from the second quarter of 2010 and down only 1 basis point from 12/31/2009 yields.
Our individual product line portfolio shows similar results. And although no insurer enjoyed this environment, we believe we are relatively well positioned for ongoing lower interest rates for a few key reasons.
Number one, we have a relatively small amount of new cash to invest in our product lines relative to the size of our existing investment portfolios, which allows our investment team to be very choosy in the assets we take from a relative value perspective.
Two, we have maintained the conservative discount rate assumptions while our new money investment opportunities benefited from the wide investment spreads of 2008 and early 2009.
Three, we’re still putting our new claim reserves each quarter at discount rates lower than the aggregate rate, which will continue to lower aggregate discount rate just as lower new money yields will lower the overall portfolio yield. And lastly, we have the ability to reprise many of our product lines which allows us to price for lower interest rates over time.
So to sum up, while today’s lower interest rates are a challenge, I believe we’re well positioned to tolerate this environment.
So with solid financial and investment results book value per share continues to grow. The company’s book value per share was $28.08 at September 30, 2010, an increase of 13% relative to a year ago. Looking at our capital, our statutory earnings continued to be quite healthy which drives a very sound capital position for the company.
Net income on a statutory basis for our traditional U.S. life insurance subsidiaries in the third quarter was $148 million, in line with a roughly $150 million we’ve been generating.
This healthy level of earnings resulting growth in our capital base at our insurance subsidiaries and improvement in our RBC ratio to approximately 410%, which is above the range we have set out for ourselves. Holding company cash and marketable securities remained at a very strong level totaling $1.03 billion at quarter end.
During the third quarter, we issued $400 million of 10-year senior notes, primarily to fund the payment of a debt maturity of $225 million in the first quarter of 2011.
In addition, we have recently used $100 million of the proceeds for an additional pension contribution which occurred in October after the close of the third quarter and this is an acceleration of the pension plan contribution we expected to make in 2011.
With the $400 million debt issuance, our leverage ratio is now 23.3%; however, this will decline by approximately 200 basis points as we pay up the debt maturing in the first quarter next year.
We also continue to return capital to shareholders by buying back our shares, repurchasing 9.5 million shares in the third quarter. We have been opportunistic in buying back shares when the price has been below, with this quarter’s repurchases done at an average share price of $20.91. We have approximately $173 million remaining of the $500 million authorized by our Board in May.
I’ll close with the comment on our outlook for the remainder of 2010. Our outlook a year ago coming into 2010 which for operating income growth within a range of 4% to 6%.
e believe that the lower end of this range is more likely for operating earnings growth for the full year 2010 with continued challenging results expected from our U.K. operations in the near term. However, given our share repurchases, we anticipate operating earnings per share towards the higher end of that target range. We will discuss this as well as our outlook for 2011 at our investor meeting on November 17.
Now, I will turn it back to Tom for his closing comments.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. As I said earlier, I continue to generally be pleased with our results, while the economic and competitive conditions remain challenging. We are benefiting from a disciplined, more diversified business model and strong capital position. Whil
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. As I said earlier, I continue to generally be pleased with our results, while the economic and competitive conditions remain challenging. We are benefiting from a disciplined, more diversified business model and strong capital position. While it may be difficult to see today, I also think the investments we’re making in our businesses today are positioning us well for the future.
As Rick said, we look forward to discussing this with you further at our Investor Day meeting in New York in November, and if you haven’t already done so, you can register for the meeting through our Web site or by contacting our Investor Relations office.
This completes our formal comments, and Tim let’s move to the question-and-answer session.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions) We will take our first question from Darin Arita with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: (Operator instructions) We will take our first question from Darin Arita with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Question on the RBC ratio, it’s up to 410%. How higher are you willing to let that increase to?
componenttext: Good morning. Question on the RBC ratio, it’s up to 410%. How higher are you willing to let that increase to?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Darin. It’s Rick. When you look at the 410%, I think we had talked about a range of 375 to 400, so we’re actually above that range today. We’re very fortunate that statutory earnings have pushed that level, but I think it’s above the
componenttext: Good morning, Darin. It’s Rick. When you look at the 410%, I think we had talked about a range of 375 to 400, so we’re actually above that range today. We’re very fortunate that statutory earnings have pushed that level, but I think it’s above the range that we have set out for ourselves already. So, I don’t think we’d expect it to go much higher. At the same time you’re seeing us buying back stock and returning capital to our investors at a rate consistent with the earnings that we’re generating. So, we feel very good about where we are from a capital perspective, but we have no desire to let that grow further.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, is that fair to assume that the dividends out of the insurance sub should increase and be pretty steady from here?
componenttext: So, is that fair to assume that the dividends out of the insurance sub should increase and be pretty steady from here?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it’s actually been pretty steady, and we’ll expect those dividends to do similarly, you would note our holding company cash also we don’t need to take the dividend out but we’d like to keep a very steady operating model of cash upstreaming
componenttext: I think it’s actually been pretty steady, and we’ll expect those dividends to do similarly, you would note our holding company cash also we don’t need to take the dividend out but we’d like to keep a very steady operating model of cash upstreaming consistent with the earnings that we’re generating in those subsidiaries.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Turning to the U.K., you have (inaudible) very well regarded. I guess, what are we planning to do differently in the U.K.?
componenttext: Turning to the U.K., you have (inaudible) very well regarded. I guess, what are we planning to do differently in the U.K.?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could Darin, let me just sort of set the stage a little bit before I ask Jack may be to make a few comments on his observations, but I think as you and others know for the last couple of years as we’ve been talking about our U.K. business, we’ve
componenttext:
If I could Darin, let me just sort of set the stage a little bit before I ask Jack may be to make a few comments on his observations, but I think as you and others know for the last couple of years as we’ve been talking about our U.K. business, we’ve been talking about the fact that the generous margins that we win so fortunate to be able to experience are probably not sustainable just because they are going to invite competition and as that competition comes in, we expect that our margins to certainly come down.
The other thing too as we certainly didn’t see any acquisitions that I think that continue to help support those higher levels of margin. What we certainly didn’t expect was the really venomous level of competitive dynamics that Jack can talk to in that market, nor we expect the economy obviously to soften to the extent it did. But I think just to set the stage, to why I thought a change was necessary. It certainly wasn’t about a quarter, it wasn’t about feeling concerned about our business and prices, and it was more about just concerned about the speed by which we are addressing the short-term issues which are really more competitive market conditions and economic issues.
But then the other part there is also the speed by which we’re positioning ourselves to benefit, when I think there is tremendous set of growth opportunities there. So, that’s really was behind the change. You are right, Jack has got a tremendous track record in things that he has done. We have a lot of confidence in that business. It’s still our highest ROE business, as Rick said in his comment. I think Jack has been there since was the middle of July, and I think Jack you’ve had a chance to get some pretty good observations on things, and they just turn to you just to share some of those insights.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. Darin, I think the things we are focusing on really two fold. The first is improving our operations. The U.K. is now finding itself operating in a competitive environment that’s more similar to the environment that the U.S. is operated i
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. Darin, I think the things we are focusing on really two fold. The first is improving our operations. The U.K. is now finding itself operating in a competitive environment that’s more similar to the environment that the U.S. is operated in over the last several years.
Fortunately, the margins are higher in the U.K., but a lot of the things that you need to do to succeed in the U.K. as similar to the things we did in the U.S. those would be focusing on pricing and underwriting discipline, make sure we’re controlling the rates we’re quoting, having milestone sign-offs, increasing the focus of underwriting and sales on profitability and implementing some of the comprehensive renewal programs that we had in the U.S., here within the U.K. in order to improve margins.
We’re also going to bring across a lot of the claims management processes that we’ve developed over the last couple of years within the U.S. and implement those in the U.K. I note that it’s a well worn path that we’re implementing; it’s something we’ve done before in the U.S.; it’s something that I personally was involved in both within underwriting and the claims process and we believe that by bringing those best practices over here we will be able to buck against the competitive headwinds we’re facing, continue to get strong margins and continue to improve results.
The second piece of that though beyond kind of shoring up the business with operational and financial controls relates to really tapping into the untapped market over here. In the U.K. only one out of 10 employees in the private sector are currently covered for a group income protection, that’s probably 70% to 80% in the U.S., Canada and several other developed countries. So we want to take a good run at expanding that coverage. We think that’s a huge growth opportunity within the U.K. The time is right both in terms of what’s happening in the government as well as in employee benefits and we hope to capitalize on that.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: Great, thank you.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: Good morning, Mark.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess kind of want to follow up on that on the U.K. I mean, on the one hand, loss ratios were higher I think probably than most people on this call had expected. But on the other hand, we’re still talking about a 20% ROE business. So, I guess the ques
componenttext: I guess kind of want to follow up on that on the U.K. I mean, on the one hand, loss ratios were higher I think probably than most people on this call had expected. But on the other hand, we’re still talking about a 20% ROE business. So, I guess the question I have is, one is, may be you talk about pricing discipline. Is there opportunity to push price given where margins are in the U.K and given where the competitive landscape is? Is it more driven by claim handling procedures changes or should we be really thinking about this kind of level of loss ratio experience as kind of a new normal?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jack, I know you’ve got all those in your mind. Why don’t you take that one?
componenttext: Jack, I know you’ve got all those in your mind. Why don’t you take that one?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I do think prices have eroded in the marketplace over the past two years. I think there is recognition in the U.K that’s it’s been a very soft market and that it’s not in the best interest of carriers, intermediaries or anyone to continue in that di
componenttext:
I do think prices have eroded in the marketplace over the past two years. I think there is recognition in the U.K that’s it’s been a very soft market and that it’s not in the best interest of carriers, intermediaries or anyone to continue in that direction. So, we are the market leader in the U.K. If prices are going to happen in the U.K, we need to participate in that. So, that will be a part of pricing discipline with an attempt to make sure we shore up margin, make sure they don’t continue to erode and face pressure for the economy, but do it in a strategic and really targeted way so that we minimize the impact on our in-force block where we’re improving margins.
From a claims management perspective, there is a big difference between claims management practices within the U.K and what we had done within the U.S. My read on that one is kind of a why won’t you do it? We have solid practices; we know how to implement it. We are confident that it can improve results. It’s a better process both from everyone’s perspective, both internally with regulators and with claimants and employers. So, it just makes sense to implement that.
We do believe, our margin in claims management relative to competitors is not as wide as it’s been in the past by implementing these practices, we think we can begin to spread that out a little bit and give us more opportunity to grow the market and invest in it.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, if I could add to that. I think that really therefore when you look at the financial results, I think probably the pricing actions is more important as you think about financial result, when Jack talked about claims improvement, those are certainly
componenttext: Mark, if I could add to that. I think that really therefore when you look at the financial results, I think probably the pricing actions is more important as you think about financial result, when Jack talked about claims improvement, those are certainly the things that be sure we position ourselves in the market in terms of the quality and consistency of our performance which we think has leveraged in terms of growing the market.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess one other question on the discount rate and commentary around portfolio yields which seemed to be holding up and the spread to the discount rate seems pretty healthy above what you target. If rates stayed kind of where we are, at what point would
componenttext: I guess one other question on the discount rate and commentary around portfolio yields which seemed to be holding up and the spread to the discount rate seems pretty healthy above what you target. If rates stayed kind of where we are, at what point would you need to make a discount rate change or do we have several quarters so that doesn’t really come into play?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly have several quarters that doesn’t come into play, and maybe even talking in terms of years, in terms of how that looks, we’re getting through this environment very well. I’ll tell you our investment team is being very opportunistic, so
componenttext: We certainly have several quarters that doesn’t come into play, and maybe even talking in terms of years, in terms of how that looks, we’re getting through this environment very well. I’ll tell you our investment team is being very opportunistic, so we haven’t seen our margin that we talk about, the distance between our asset yields and our discount rates deteriorate at all in this environment. I think we may have lost a couple of basis points related to our disability rates, but still well in excess of our margin. So, I don’t think we feel under pressure today to do a whole lot of them from it.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rick, if I could add to. I think actually just to give it, you made the point in your comments, but we don’t have a lot to put out actually and it’s because again we work very hard from an asset liability point of view to be sure that we spread out ou
componenttext: Rick, if I could add to. I think actually just to give it, you made the point in your comments, but we don’t have a lot to put out actually and it’s because again we work very hard from an asset liability point of view to be sure that we spread out our maturities and match our liabilities very carefully. I think actually between now and the end of the year we have about $100 million to put on to the marketplace which just gives you a sense as to how little investment activity is really happening in this environment.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. Interesting. Okay, thank you.
componenttext: Right. Interesting. Okay, thank you.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark.
componenttext: Thanks, Mark.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we’ll take our next question from John Nadel with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: And we’ll take our next question from John Nadel with Sterne Agee.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, good morning, everybody. So, Rick I wanted to come back to your comments on capital and buybacks for a moment. As we think about excess capital and deployment is it fair to us to look upon especially given the risk-based capital ratio at the insuranc
componenttext: Hey, good morning, everybody. So, Rick I wanted to come back to your comments on capital and buybacks for a moment. As we think about excess capital and deployment is it fair to us to look upon especially given the risk-based capital ratio at the insurance subs is it fair to us to look upon that billion dollars of cash to the holding company, maybe net of the $225 million debt maturity in March is fully deployable? If so, what time period should we be looking at in terms of expectations for deploying that capital?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, if I look at the holding company capital specifically, I think you’re right take that billion dollars hair cut back to with 225 we have effectively prefunded for our maturity coming up in the first quarter, and also hair cut $100 million off of tha
componenttext: Yes, if I look at the holding company capital specifically, I think you’re right take that billion dollars hair cut back to with 225 we have effectively prefunded for our maturity coming up in the first quarter, and also hair cut $100 million off of that, that we put into retention. So, there is excess there. In this environment we probably would still look to around two times coverage, as a holding company, which is quite conservative but probably a good benchmark. One times coverage is roughly $250 million. So, there is excess there. But think it is very much as a capital run rate generation that we’ve seen over multiple quarters and returning that capital to shareholders.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, two times coverage $500 million bucks, really?
componenttext: So, two times coverage $500 million bucks, really?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I said that was conservative. It is very conservative.
componenttext: Yes. I said that was conservative. It is very conservative.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s very conservative. And then I guess related to excess capital, I guess, question on M&A has there been any pickup in M&A opportunities in the group insurance area, I mean, we see the pressure from the companies that we actively cover, but I have
componenttext: That’s very conservative. And then I guess related to excess capital, I guess, question on M&A has there been any pickup in M&A opportunities in the group insurance area, I mean, we see the pressure from the companies that we actively cover, but I have to assume there’s so many other smaller players out there that must be struggling as well. And potentially might view the current environment as an opportunity to change their view on what they believe is a core business, I mean, is anything changing along those lines?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the group space, I think people still like the business. It’s generating good returns for people. So that’s the one that people are hanging on to and concentrating on to see that sometimes in the competitive environment there are oppo
componenttext:
When you look at the group space, I think people still like the business. It’s generating good returns for people. So that’s the one that people are hanging on to and concentrating on to see that sometimes in the competitive environment there are opportunities out there.
I think the most important thing as we look at those opportunities, one we have the capital to transact that we just talked about, but they have to have the right fit. We have to be getting something more. We’ll do a financial transaction, but it will be with a very high hurdle, but we have to be getting something out of the deal as well. So, I’d tell you there is still a pretty sparse market in the group space that M&A will be a big part of the growth strategy, but we’re certainly looking, and we’re certainly well known out there that we would be a buyer in many situations.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Finally, I’d be remiss, you guys have probably more this quarter in your prepared remarks than I can recall over the past couple of quarters. The competitive environment, aggressive competition are terms that I think we’ve heard at least a few times o
componenttext: Finally, I’d be remiss, you guys have probably more this quarter in your prepared remarks than I can recall over the past couple of quarters. The competitive environment, aggressive competition are terms that I think we’ve heard at least a few times on this call. Any update you can provide us to where the competitive environment sits if you think about it relative to last quarter, the quarter before, I mean, we’re coming up on a very important sales period. What’s your expectations around that terms and conditions just getting that much more aggressive?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, maybe we’ll ask Kevin to speak for the U.S., maybe Jack if you could make a couple of comments about the U.K. but Kevin.
componenttext: John, maybe we’ll ask Kevin to speak for the U.S., maybe Jack if you could make a couple of comments about the U.K. but Kevin.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t think there is so much terms and conditions, I think it’s a lot of price. As I said last quarter, incumbent carriers, in-force carriers are continuing to defend their in-force blocks, I think primarily driven by the fact that they want to main
componenttext:
I don’t think there is so much terms and conditions, I think it’s a lot of price. As I said last quarter, incumbent carriers, in-force carriers are continuing to defend their in-force blocks, I think primarily driven by the fact that they want to maintain their end premium levels, they want to maintain their field service organization and this has been with employment or the economy now turning around, new sales are just adding across the board in the industry.
As we track pricing levels using some outside research support, industry pricing levels continue to slide downward. They haven’t flattened and they certainly haven’t turned in the other direction. We are entering the 2011 renewal season. We would have expected maybe based on some comments we heard in the marketplace that renewals might be easy to place but we haven’t seen that so far. We see competition on business that we’re putting out to renew just as aggressive or maybe even more aggressive than it’s been in the past couple of years. So, bottom line is, I’m not seeing any hardening.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of that pricing level sliding downwards, can you give a sense as to order of magnitude there?
componenttext: In terms of that pricing level sliding downwards, can you give a sense as to order of magnitude there?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just the fact that it doesn’t really take very much, maybe sliding down a couple of points, something like that. On any given case thought, when you’ve got four, five carriers bidding, the spreads can be quite wide.
componenttext: Just the fact that it doesn’t really take very much, maybe sliding down a couple of points, something like that. On any given case thought, when you’ve got four, five carriers bidding, the spreads can be quite wide.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jack, do you have a quick comment on the U.K.?
componenttext: Jack, do you have a quick comment on the U.K.?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Within the U.K., I think there is a lot of pressure. It’s a little different. We have 50% of the market in the U.K. If you think about our persistency 2009 to 2010 improved 3.5%. So, that puts a lot of pressure on competitors from pricing perspective. A
componenttext:
Within the U.K., I think there is a lot of pressure. It’s a little different. We have 50% of the market in the U.K. If you think about our persistency 2009 to 2010 improved 3.5%. So, that puts a lot of pressure on competitors from pricing perspective. Anyway, I think there is a lot of pressure on the fourth quarter. Unlike the U.S., the fourth quarter is not the big quarter in the U.K. it’s actually April was our biggest renewal month.
So, it’s a little bit different, a little bit delayed. But there are a lot of competitors out there that are starving for sales. We are looking to raise the pricing umbrella. We’re probably going to have to suffer a little bit in persistency for that to happen with the expectation that rates will harden certainly in the second half of next year.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s great. Thank you very much for all the color.
componenttext: That’s great. Thank you very much for all the color.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good. Thanks, John.
componenttext: Good. Thanks, John.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we’ll take our next question from Tom Gallagher with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And we’ll take our next question from Tom Gallagher with Credit Suisse.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. First question is, can you talk a bit about statutory earnings trends? Those have remained pretty strong. Overall, $600 million sort of annualized, a pretty good run rate here, especially as we consider a sustained low rate environment. Is t
componenttext: Good morning. First question is, can you talk a bit about statutory earnings trends? Those have remained pretty strong. Overall, $600 million sort of annualized, a pretty good run rate here, especially as we consider a sustained low rate environment. Is there any stat impact that you would expect to see as a result of low rates or do you think we still will see a pretty steady level of earnings power including in the U.K., are you still generating the same level of say cash earnings that you’d be able to take out of the U.K.? That’s my first question.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the stat earnings, they are actually, the generation we saw $150 million, that’s still been a very steady run rate. So a lot can happen, but we see that very consistently as we look to the future. Specifically to interest rates, there a
componenttext:
When you look at the stat earnings, they are actually, the generation we saw $150 million, that’s still been a very steady run rate. So a lot can happen, but we see that very consistently as we look to the future. Specifically to interest rates, there are impact that can happen with lowering of discount rates on a statutory basis, but we see that baked into our results and still be able to generate that clean $150 million roughly a quarter.
When you look to the U.K., I think those earnings there will come down a little bit commensurately with what you’re seeing there on the GAAP side, so they will be a little bit lower earnings run rate that we see in the U.K. but nothing that we are overly concerned about. So, if I take you back to slide we were showing at our Investor Day last year, the overall capital generation in the company still is very good and we expect that to continue.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rick, is there any pressure coming from the long-term care business in any way, shape or form whether it’s GAAP or whether it’s on statutory financials and then what subsidiary would the long-term care book or most of it be in on a regulatory basis?
componenttext: Rick, is there any pressure coming from the long-term care business in any way, shape or form whether it’s GAAP or whether it’s on statutory financials and then what subsidiary would the long-term care book or most of it be in on a regulatory basis?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Most of our long-term care book was written out of Unum America. So, that’s where you would see the LTC business was written. When you look at the pressure there, I don’t feel any particular pressure different than we would have seen years ago at LTC,
componenttext: Most of our long-term care book was written out of Unum America. So, that’s where you would see the LTC business was written. When you look at the pressure there, I don’t feel any particular pressure different than we would have seen years ago at LTC, the individual business, which we have stopped writing, is a more challenging business, that’s why we’re not writing it. But I haven’t seen the trend lines on that business change very much from what we would have seen over a number of years. So, I’d say no additional pressure we see there.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now, I guess just getting back on the U.K., as we think about that business, is there any riskier of a reserve review of and anything else that we should be aware of from a margin standpoint? I mean, it sounds like it’s a challenging environment, but is
componenttext: Now, I guess just getting back on the U.K., as we think about that business, is there any riskier of a reserve review of and anything else that we should be aware of from a margin standpoint? I mean, it sounds like it’s a challenging environment, but is it really just an issue of looking at operating earnings or could there be something beyond that? Whenever I hear a situation where things are in flux and restructuring, to some extent, that’s one question that comes up, can you address that question on the U.K.?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, when you look at the U.K., I’ll first start off with the margins. This business is still very high. So, they are lower than one would have seen, but those are off of what we would have said and we did say we have very lofty level, so you have to st
componenttext: Yes, when you look at the U.K., I’ll first start off with the margins. This business is still very high. So, they are lower than one would have seen, but those are off of what we would have said and we did say we have very lofty level, so you have to start there before we talk about the pressure. As we’ve seen the loss ratio creep up into the 60%, 67% range that’s even higher than we would have seen a quarter ago. So, there is pressure there on recognizing that but that’s more of an earnings run rate issue than anything else from a structuring perspective. As Jack mentioned, as he looks at the business and different practices he wants to bring in and how there will be change to go on there, but I don’t see anything material on that front.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jack, just one last for you. I know you talked a bit about best practices on claims handling, if you successfully overlaid your U.S. best practices on the U.K. business, are we talking about a 50 basis point improvement on the benefit ratio or 500 basis p
componenttext: Jack, just one last for you. I know you talked a bit about best practices on claims handling, if you successfully overlaid your U.S. best practices on the U.K. business, are we talking about a 50 basis point improvement on the benefit ratio or 500 basis points. Can you help sort of frame what you think the opportunity there would be?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it’s really hard to predict what the opportunity will be. I think it’s pretty clear that we can improve things through increasing the rigor of the practices and putting the appropriate resources on it. There are some differences between the U.
componenttext: I think it’s really hard to predict what the opportunity will be. I think it’s pretty clear that we can improve things through increasing the rigor of the practices and putting the appropriate resources on it. There are some differences between the U.S. and the U.K. in terms of practices that would make it hard to predict from the U.S. experience just how much things can improve in the U.K. We’re very optimistic that we can make things better, but I think we’d be reluctant to put a number around what the improvement would be.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks.
componenttext: Okay, thanks.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom.
componenttext: Thanks, Tom.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we’ll take our next question from Chris Giovanni with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we’ll take our next question from Chris Giovanni with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks so much. Tom, in your Investor Day you’d highlighted that capital management could contribute 3% to 5% earnings growth on a normalized basis, so if we assume the Board approves another buyback authorization when the existing one is exhausted, wou
componenttext: Thanks so much. Tom, in your Investor Day you’d highlighted that capital management could contribute 3% to 5% earnings growth on a normalized basis, so if we assume the Board approves another buyback authorization when the existing one is exhausted, would you expect to see this 3% to 5% annual benefit over the next couple of years?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rick, you want to take that one? I think these are some of the things we’ll talk about Investor Day actually.
componenttext: Rick, you want to take that one? I think these are some of the things we’ll talk about Investor Day actually.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We won’t talk about Investor Day, but I think that was done or 3% to 5% was consistent with what we ended up doing here as we authorize a $500 million buyback. We’ll obviously have to talk to our Board about what we’re going to do, but it all comes
componenttext: We won’t talk about Investor Day, but I think that was done or 3% to 5% was consistent with what we ended up doing here as we authorize a $500 million buyback. We’ll obviously have to talk to our Board about what we’re going to do, but it all comes back to the earnings generation, and the statutory earnings, and returning that to shareholder. So, when you pull that all back and returning that capital and concentrating our shareholder base effectively we’ll generate those kind of earnings growth rates.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Chris, if I could add too. I think one of the things you can surely sense is that, we’re very confident that our business model is capable of producing much more consistent results including statutory results, and I think Rick touched on it. When you ha
componenttext: Chris, if I could add too. I think one of the things you can surely sense is that, we’re very confident that our business model is capable of producing much more consistent results including statutory results, and I think Rick touched on it. When you have that consistent delivery of statutory results that makes available free cash flow, as you have a lot of choices in terms how you put that cash flow to work. To my second point, if you look at the last three years, we have to be one of the only companies that has been out there fairly aggressively on share buybacks as well as dividend increases and I think that’s just part of our MO going forward.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: One follow-up for Kevin. In terms of the group disability side Unum U.S., a number of the larger competitors’ people have talked about have seen adverse loss experience and are beginning to talk about taking rate increases. Would you expect that some of
componenttext: One follow-up for Kevin. In terms of the group disability side Unum U.S., a number of the larger competitors’ people have talked about have seen adverse loss experience and are beginning to talk about taking rate increases. Would you expect that some of these plans are shopped around? You may be get some more looks than you’ve gotten in the past, or do you think looking at price way too up to begin with mid single digit price increases doesn’t make the risk appropriate?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t know if we will get more looks than we had in the past. But just as the market share leader, we tend to get pretty much all the looks that are out there. We have got the broadest field wholesale retail distribution system out there as well. But,
componenttext: I don’t know if we will get more looks than we had in the past. But just as the market share leader, we tend to get pretty much all the looks that are out there. We have got the broadest field wholesale retail distribution system out there as well. But, I think if competitors start to raise rate in this economy, I think that will be good for stabilizing the risk environment, and I think that the quality of our field force and the diversity of our portfolio would see some benefit from that, yes.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you.
componenttext: Okay, thank you.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good, Thanks, Chris.
componenttext: Good, Thanks, Chris.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we’ll take our next question from Mark Hughes with SunTrust.
componenttext: And we’ll take our next question from Mark Hughes with SunTrust.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. Good morning. In understanding that you’ve been doing some consumer advertising in select market to support the voluntary business, and if so, what kind of results have you seen from that?
componenttext: Thank you very much. Good morning. In understanding that you’ve been doing some consumer advertising in select market to support the voluntary business, and if so, what kind of results have you seen from that?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it’s a good question, Mark. Maybe I will ask Kevin to state that because actually we’ve been doing that mostly in Kevin’s market.
componenttext: Yes, it’s a good question, Mark. Maybe I will ask Kevin to state that because actually we’ve been doing that mostly in Kevin’s market.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the last year or so we’ve been doing some consumer advertising, primarily targeted in the four cities in the United States, trying to track changes in consumer awareness of our brand, and trying to see whether the change in that awareness generates b
componenttext: In the last year or so we’ve been doing some consumer advertising, primarily targeted in the four cities in the United States, trying to track changes in consumer awareness of our brand, and trying to see whether the change in that awareness generates both increased quote activity, as well as increased maybe participation in voluntary cases. It’s still pretty early to sort of quantify whether or not those outcomes are going to be. So the outcomes that we want, but I think early indicators are that they are helpful, the advertising has been helpful.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then there has been some discussion about brokers maybe focusing a little bit more on voluntary benefits with health commission threatened to be cut. Are you seeing that?
componenttext: And then there has been some discussion about brokers maybe focusing a little bit more on voluntary benefits with health commission threatened to be cut. Are you seeing that?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our simply Unum platform results would allow those brokers to integrate group and voluntary coverage. Since the Unum sales are very robust and up and occupy a greater and greater share of our small case markets growth and more and more brokers are partici
componenttext: Our simply Unum platform results would allow those brokers to integrate group and voluntary coverage. Since the Unum sales are very robust and up and occupy a greater and greater share of our small case markets growth and more and more brokers are participating in the voluntary market, more and more brokers are asking for information and looking for support in that voluntary market, and we think we’re just positioned great for that.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could add to that, Mark. I think as you know, we made a pretty strong commitment a few years ago to the belief that the market was going to move more in the voluntary direction, and obviously we’ve got two businesses in the U.S. that are beneficiar
componenttext: If I could add to that, Mark. I think as you know, we made a pretty strong commitment a few years ago to the belief that the market was going to move more in the voluntary direction, and obviously we’ve got two businesses in the U.S. that are beneficiaries of that, so only Kevin’s business the Unum continue to have very strong voluntary sales here this year, Randy’s business the Colonial continue to have the same result. We like the fact that we’ve got two businesses positioned to sort of capitalize on what a very clear movement towards a voluntary business.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you.
componenttext: Great, thank you.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: And we’ll take our next question from Ed Spehar from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Two questions, first I wanted to go back to the U.K. and the comment that the U.K. is looking more like the U.S. but still higher margins. Can you give us some sense of where you think the U.K. ROE normalizes? And then I have one
componenttext: Thank you. Good morning. Two questions, first I wanted to go back to the U.K. and the comment that the U.K. is looking more like the U.S. but still higher margins. Can you give us some sense of where you think the U.K. ROE normalizes? And then I have one follow-up.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jack, do you want to take that question?
componenttext: Jack, do you want to take that question?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think our expectation right now given the look at the margins and where we are, is certainly over the long-term we don’t expect any further deterioration in the ROE. So, we would pegged at 20% which is where it is now with some optimism around these p
componenttext: I think our expectation right now given the look at the margins and where we are, is certainly over the long-term we don’t expect any further deterioration in the ROE. So, we would pegged at 20% which is where it is now with some optimism around these pricing changes if the market does react to that as well as if we can get some footholds in the claim processing changes, we think there are opportunities to improve it.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: But I guess the question would be, that doesn’t sound like it looks very much like the U.S.?
componenttext: But I guess the question would be, that doesn’t sound like it looks very much like the U.S.?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was talking about the U.S. in the terms of the erosion of margins and the level of competitiveness as opposed to the absolute level of margins. The absolute level continues to be significantly higher. It started from a much higher level than the U.S. di
componenttext: I was talking about the U.S. in the terms of the erosion of margins and the level of competitiveness as opposed to the absolute level of margins. The absolute level continues to be significantly higher. It started from a much higher level than the U.S. did. It’s a much narrower market than the U.S. So, my comments will more from a relative perspective to where it had been historically as opposed to comparing margins in the U.S. and the U.K. because they are much stronger, have always been much stronger and would expect to continue that way.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: There too, Jack also, when he speaks to a lot of the operational efficiencies we can get by using best practices from the U.S., maybe more aggressively in the U.K. and that’s also a source of value including the fact that we’re rolling out a new offer
componenttext: There too, Jack also, when he speaks to a lot of the operational efficiencies we can get by using best practices from the U.S., maybe more aggressively in the U.K. and that’s also a source of value including the fact that we’re rolling out a new offering that’s very similar to Simply Unum as you know we rolled out about year-and-a-half ago here in the U.S. We’re rolling that out in the U.K. actually here this month. So, the other part of this is just the leveraging of the core capabilities that we have that are proven elsewhere and maybe more quickly accelerate the usage of those in the U.K. as well.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s significantly more concentrated. There are basically four players in the group income protection market, there’s us, Canada Life, Aviva and L&G. I think those four players account for some 80% of the market over here.
componenttext: It’s significantly more concentrated. There are basically four players in the group income protection market, there’s us, Canada Life, Aviva and L&G. I think those four players account for some 80% of the market over here.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you. That’s helpful. And then just the question on capital for Rick. If you look at other, I would say, well-run disability companies or group insurance companies, StanCorp talks about an RBC target of 300%. I understand your business is dif
componenttext: Okay. Thank you. That’s helpful. And then just the question on capital for Rick. If you look at other, I would say, well-run disability companies or group insurance companies, StanCorp talks about an RBC target of 300%. I understand your business is different, you have the U.K. piece. But I am curious why 375% to 400% RBC plus 2x holding company requirements isn’t an excessively conservative level of capital?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: When we look at the level of capital that we’re holding, I think it’s trying to be reflective of the environment. I think some of our peers that you mentioned are running at higher levels as well. They just haven’t changed their benchmark. I think w
componenttext:
When we look at the level of capital that we’re holding, I think it’s trying to be reflective of the environment. I think some of our peers that you mentioned are running at higher levels as well. They just haven’t changed their benchmark. I think what are trying to say is, we want to reflect the environment. So in a more difficult environment I define that on a couple of fronts.
One would be, what we see in the economy still which is challenging, you see that in unemployment and wage role. You can also see it in terms of the dynamic regulatory environment that we see around us, I think being a little bit more conservative makes sense. Do we need to hold there, is that a new level that we expect the company to run at going forward? Probably not, but in today’s environment, those are the levels that we think are dictated by this environment that we’re in.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So but when you think about how you price products, so you are competing against players that are looking at lower RBC ratios, what do you consider as your target? When you’re talking of pricing actuaries and you’re saying this is how we write busines
componenttext: So but when you think about how you price products, so you are competing against players that are looking at lower RBC ratios, what do you consider as your target? When you’re talking of pricing actuaries and you’re saying this is how we write business, what’s the target used pricing formulas?

componenttext: I will probably give you the specifics on that, but it’s going to be lower that we are running the company at today for that exact reason that we’re running with excess given the environment around us. That is not our long-term expectation of the capital we have, and it also is product dependent. I won’t get specific with those obviously, but it is south of certainly where we are running at the company today.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Just a couple of quick ones. First, I guess for Jack, there is sort of upward trend in the benefit ratio here in the U.K. How much longer does he think that’s going to go on? Secondly for Kevin, you’re pretty much through the renewal sea
componenttext:
Good morning. Just a couple of quick ones. First, I guess for Jack, there is sort of upward trend in the benefit ratio here in the U.K. How much longer does he think that’s going to go on? Secondly for Kevin, you’re pretty much through the renewal season now. In terms of premium growth that you are looking at next year, is it going to be fairly similar to what we have seen this year and there’s no surprise given the economy, but just to sort of set that up?
And then turning to then supplemental on voluntary, in many ways it was a tough quarter I guess in terms of returns. If you want to call them competitors now since you are not writing individual long-term care anymore, have announced some fairly steep rate hikes over the past quarter. The interest adjusted loss ratio there sure setting I guess the second highest in your company’s history. Is there anything you can do to start to improve this? Are we going to be looking at this thing sitting over 80% for a while?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let’s go back to your first question. Jack, you want to take the question about your sense of the benefit ratio in the U.K.?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. My sense of the benefit ratio is certainly the level of deterioration in it will slow. Our premiums have begun to level out over the last couple of quarters. That’s been a factor in the benefit ratio. Depending on what happens, I think we might see
componenttext: Yes. My sense of the benefit ratio is certainly the level of deterioration in it will slow. Our premiums have begun to level out over the last couple of quarters. That’s been a factor in the benefit ratio. Depending on what happens, I think we might see some pressure for the next couple of quarter but I would expect beyond that by the second half of next year we would have stabilized and begun to improve it.

componenttext: 2011, we’re down versus the program, while the program is slightly higher in terms of volumes than it was in 2010 and the average rate increases will be probably slightly higher, especially may be in the core market a little bit just reflecting the economic environment. But I think we got to be careful that we know that our persistency is already quite high, that’s been shoring up our earned premium levels, while the sales of our internal lag. So, we’re going to be careful to monitor the little progress quarter-by-quarter.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in group long-term care, first of all, we continue to be in that market. It’s a valuable part of our portfolio consistent with the brokers that we do voluntary benefits with, and it’s very consistent with our employee benefit strategy. Much of o
componenttext:
Well, in group long-term care, first of all, we continue to be in that market. It’s a valuable part of our portfolio consistent with the brokers that we do voluntary benefits with, and it’s very consistent with our employee benefit strategy. Much of our groups long-term care business includes employer funding, the average age is still quite in fact middle of the workforce in the mid-40s.
That said, we have the ability to reprice group long-term care because it is a group product, and we continue to evaluate sort of over the course of time what the right level of pricing is and how do we make sure that pricing matches up with the interest rate environment, in particular.
But in terms of operational expense, group long-term care has performed quite well. On the individual side, we are no longer writing business, we’re in the process of looking at what kind of rate increase will be necessary to show up that book of business and we’ll be rolling that through a number of discussions with state regulators over the next several weeks, and then we will have more report in a few weeks.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: That’s a long answer, Colin. No, we’re just focused on the basics with our field force. We’re really emphasizing the service side of our business, and getting our agents back out to visit our enforce customers, and spending time with them doing benefits counseling. In many cases that, that doesn’t add to sales and in many others it does, but at least gets our folks out in front of our existing customers and we’re just staying after that and having nice steady and even improving persistency results as you pointed out. So, I think it just comes back to a strong area focus for us.

Hi, thanks. Good morning. I was actually going to ask about Colonial too, and I guess I think the Colin just get on it but your largest competitors have been having trouble really in recruiting, I guess, to see the sales are holding up and so I’m just wondering if there is an update on what sectors are working, you said public sectors was down and commercial was okay. But just understanding how that’s a better story for colonial versus that large competitor.
And then just on the recruiting front that seems to be going well for you as well. Comments from the competitor have been that it’s hard to recruit folks with unemployment checks persisting and salary jobs more attractive just trying to get more color on what’s making Colonial work so well?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I sure am, Tom. I think the answer there is really intertwined for both sides of that. I mean we are very focused on growing our agency distribution system. We continue to have very good results there quarter-over-quarter. We’re up near 20% on a ye
componenttext:
Yes, I sure am, Tom. I think the answer there is really intertwined for both sides of that. I mean we are very focused on growing our agency distribution system. We continue to have very good results there quarter-over-quarter. We’re up near 20% on a year-to-date basis in terms of new rep contracts and we’re working very hard to make more and more of those folks productive as early as possible.
So I think it’s just a matter of focus and consistency there and that’s also helping us then with our overall sales increase for the year. We’re getting a considerable lift in production from reps we’ve brought on over the last two to three years. That’s a real difference maker for us in this very tough economic environment.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: I mean just back to the recruiting issue and is that helping you to recruit because I think that, I guess the other folks in this area are just having trouble getting sales folks in the door and I mean it’s not just our flight, but it’s other smaller franchisees out there. So is that success of new people? I am just trying to understand it because it just seems like it’s hard all of a sudden to get these types of sales people on the door. Just trying to understand why the recruiting is working well?
