componenttext: Yes, I think it definitely is a success, brief success and more people wanting to come onboard and we’re getting a lot of referrals for new agents from people that have joined us in the last couple of years and it’s just snowballs in a very positive way for us.

So we had a sequential declining trend in recent quarters and I am curious when we look at 2011 given the pressures on the top line, is that a trend that you think will stabilize or should we expect earnings to continue to decline somewhat on a sequential basis based on the top line pressures?

componenttext: It’s a good lead in actually to our Investor Day which I reiterate is on November 17, but to give you the high level. I think we have seen good results in 2010 consistent with the way we laid it out in the 4% to 6% range and we will look to 2011 to give you a similar view.

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Unum Group Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. This call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tom White. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Tim. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Unum's Third Quarter 2010 Analyst and Investor Conference Call. Our remarks this morning will include forward-looking statements, which are statements that are not of current or historical fact
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Tim. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Unum's Third Quarter 2010 Analyst and Investor Conference Call. Our remarks this morning will include forward-looking statements, which are statements that are not of current or historical facts. As a result, actual results might differ materially from results suggested by these forward-looking statements. Information concerning factors that could cause results to differ appears in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and are also located in the section titled cautionary statement regarding forward-looking statements and risk factors in our annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 20'09, and also in any subsequent filed forms 10-Q. Our SEC filings can be found in the Investors section of our website at www.unum.com. Please also note that the statements in today's call speak only as of the date they are made and we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. A presentation of the most directly comparable GAAP measures and reconciliations of any non-GAAP financial measures included in today's presentation can be found on the website in the Investors section. 
Participating in this morning's conference call are Rick McKenney, Executive Vice President and CFO; and our business segment Presidents Kevin McCarthy, Randy Horn and Jeff McGarry. And now, I'd like to turn the call over to Unum's President and CEO, Tom Watjen. Tom?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom and good morning. We had another solid quarter, with operating income growth for the quarter and year-to-date remaining in line with our 2010 outlook of growth of between 4% and 6%. I would say too that we certainly benefited from our most
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom and good morning. We had another solid quarter, with operating income growth for the quarter and year-to-date remaining in line with our 2010 outlook of growth of between 4% and 6%. I would say too that we certainly benefited from our most diverse mix, as the relatively strong performance of Unum U.S. and Colonial operations, driven frankly generally by stable risks trends offset the relatively weaker performance of our Unum U.K. operation. While the economic and competitive environment both in the U.S. and U.K. remain a challenge, by staying disciplined, we have continued to generate solid profitability, including strong statutory earnings, which has enabled us to continue to repurchase stock while still retaining strong capital position. 
Now, let me just touch on a few highlights in the quarter. First, as I indicated, third quarter aftertax operating income grew 3.9%, and earnings per share grew 6.5%, which are both consistent with our 2010 outlook of growth between 4% to 6%. Second, while we saw very little change in the business and economic environment this quarter, and no substantive change in the competitive environment, we are capitalizing on profitable growth opportunities as they arise. I pointed especially to our Voluntary Benefits businesses in both the Unum U.S., where sales grew 27% in the third quarter, and Colonial, where our commercial sales grew 5.7% as good indications of how we're actually capitalizing on today's market condition. Don't get me wrong. The combination of the economy and aggressive competitors make it challenging to profitably grow the business but we feel very good about our market position. 
Third, our investment portfolio remains in excellent shape, with a net unrealized gain in our fixed maturity securities portfolio increasing as a result of the decline in interest rates and ongoing tightening of credit spreads to $5.7 billion this quarter. The flip side however, is that today's low level of interest rates and investment yields can create some challenges but we have positioned the company to effectively manage through this environment. And finally, with our solid financial results and strong investment performance, we continue to build on our very strong capital position. Our weighted average risk-based capital ratio is currently at 410% and our holding company's cash and marketable securities position is slightly over $1 million, giving us continued financial flexibility in these uncertain times. We have built these strong capital levels while also purchasing $198 million of stock during the third quarter and $328 million of stock year-to-date. 
In summary, I feel very good about our results so far this year. I think the diversity of our company is becoming more apparent. The relatively strong performance of Unum U.S. and Colonial Life operations offset the lower level of performance in the U.K. As you know, we've made a management change there and I'm confident that under John McGarry's leadership, we can more effectively operate in this difficult market environment and capitalize on the growth opportunities which I believe exist in this market. While we continue to face premium growth challenges in certain lines of business, we continue to benefit from our disciplined business approach, which has allowed us to generate capital that can be used to repurchase stock at a very opportune time. Now, I'll ask Tom White to provide an overview on our operating results this quarter. Tom?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Tom. Net income for the third quarter was $220.8 million or $0.68 per diluted common share, compared to net income of $221.1 million or $0.66 per diluted common share last year. Included in the results for the third quarter of 2010 are net
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Tom. Net income for the third quarter was $220.8 million or $0.68 per diluted common share, compared to net income of $221.1 million or $0.66 per diluted common share last year. Included in the results for the third quarter of 2010 are net realized after-tax investment gains of $0.9 million or less than $0.01 per diluted common share compared to net realized after-tax gain of $9.5 million or $0.02 per diluted common share in the third quarter of 2009. Net realized after-tax investment gains for the third quarter of 2010 include an after-tax gain of $1.1 million resulting from changes in the fair value of an embedded derivative and a modified coinsurance contract compared to an after-tax gain of $28.9 million in the third quarter of 2009. Also included in net realized after-tax investment gains for the third quarter are net realized after-tax investment losses of $200,000 related to sales and write-downs of investments compared to net after-tax losses of $19.4 million in the third quarter of 2009. Excluding these items, after-tax operating income was $219.9 million for this quarter or $0.68 per diluted common share compared to $211.6 million or $0.64 per diluted common share in the year-ago quarter. 
Turning to the operating segments, in total, Unum U.S. operating income increased 4% to $204.7 million in the third quarter. Within Unum U.S., the Group Disability line reported another solid quarter, with income of 4% to $77.8 million, driven primarily by improved risk experience on a year-over-year basis. Within the group lines and AD&D line, operating income increased 6% to $52.8 million in the third quarter. A slight improvement in premium income, as well as stable risk experience helped to generate improved earnings. 
In the Supplemental and Voluntary line, third quarter income was up 2.8% to $74.1 million from $72.1 million a year ago. The improvement was driven by strong earnings growth from the Voluntary Benefits line of business. 
Moving to Unum U.K., operating income in this segment decreased $19.6 million to $47.2 million. Operating income declined 15.1% in local currency. While premium income in local currency was essentially flat in the third quarter, the benefit ratio of 66.9% was well above the unusually low benefit ratio of the year-ago quarter. You'll recall that the third quarter of 2009 benefit ratio benefited from a reserve reduction associated with a significant reduction in the value of inflation index linked policies. This reduction in reserves was largely offset by a corresponding reduction in net investment income on index link securities. The year-over-year reduction in income reflects pressure from the economic environment on our ability to resolve claims and continued competitive pricing pressures, particularly in the Group Disability line. 
Concluding our core operations, Colonial Life had a strong quarter, with premium growth of 6.2% and operating income growth of 5.8% compared to last year. The benefit ratio was 49.9% this quarter compared with the year ago benefit ratio of 48.2%, still in line with our longer-term expectations for this business segment. 
The Individual Disability Closed Block operating income was $9.8 million compared to $7.2 million in the year-ago quarter. The interest adjusted loss ratio was higher at 85.5% this quarter compared to 81.6% in the year-ago quarter but was consistent with the second quarter of 2010. Premium income declined by 6% and net investment income was up 1% year-over-year. And finally, the corporate and other segment reported an operating loss of $10.8 million compared to a loss of $13.7 million in the year-ago quarter. Net investment income was higher, reflecting higher levels of invested assets and higher miscellaneous net investment income, while interest expense increased to $31.8 million this year compared to $24.1 million last year, reflecting the debt issuances from September of 2009 and September of 2010. So with that review of our operating results, I'll turn the call over to Rick McKenney for a deeper analysis of this quarter's results.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. In my comments, I'd like to discuss this quarter's key drivers, which have remained relatively consistent, and also cover our investment portfolio, interest rate management and our capital position. First, starting on how risk is performin
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. In my comments, I'd like to discuss this quarter's key drivers, which have remained relatively consistent, and also cover our investment portfolio, interest rate management and our capital position. First, starting on how risk is performing, across the company, it is generally stable, with some pockets of elevated experience off of last year's very favorable results. Focusing on Unum U.S., risk experience remained generally stable across all lines this quarter. Our Group Disability results remain strong, with a third quarter benefit ratio of 84.6%, lower than the year-ago quarter experience of 85.3% due to more favorable claim recovery performance and flat with the benefit ratio in the second quarter. New claim incidents for the quarter was consistent with the year ago experience but slightly elevated relative to the second quarter. The claim incidents trends are not showing notable underlying trends or any signs of being economically influenced. This quarter's results also reflect our view that our Group Disability benefit ratio will level out this year and have longer-term opportunities for improvement can be achieved gradually as our core market exposure changes with our in force mix of business. I would note that given today's challenging environment, I believe our current pretax margin of 15% and ROE of 12.6% for the third quarter for the Group Disability business lines are quite strong. Also within Unum U.S., Group Life and AD&D experience remain very steady, with the third quarter benefit ratio at 70.4% compared to 70.3% in the year-ago quarter and second quarter as well. Finally, the voluntary and supplemental lines showed favorable claims experience in the Voluntary Benefits line, with third quarter benefit ratio declining to 54.6% from 59% a year ago, offset by a slightly higher benefit ratio in the Individual Disability recently issued line due to higher average size of new claims. The long-term care line showed generally steady interest adjusted loss ratios of 80.9% in the third quarter compared to 80.8% in the second quarter and up from 77.5% in the year-ago quarter. Moving to our Unum U.K. results, risk results are worse than last year and up slightly sequentially, with the third quarter 2010 benefit ratio at 66.9%. Weaker results have a number of drivers, including lower net claim resolutions and continued competitive pricing pressures in the Group Disability line, which is only partially offset by a slight improvement in Group Life experience. The impact of inflation on the inflation-index linked group policies is generally a non-economic influence and was a significant contributor to the year ago year-over-year change in the benefit ratio but had minimal impact of a sequential quarter results. The competitive market conditions are negatively impacting our margins in the U.K. and we expect this drag to continue for the near term. I'll remind you that the Unum U.K. pretax margin was 29% and ROE was nearly 21% this quarter, still a very healthy level of profitability. And finally, Colonial Life's risk results this quarter were somewhat unfavorable in the accidents, sickness and disability line of business, and drove the benefit ratio for the quarter to just under 50% compared to 48.2% in the year-ago quarter. As we had mentioned before, we believe that the benefit ratio of around 50% is likely an ongoing expectation for Colonial Life as a whole. 
Turning to the premium line, the challenges continue in today's economic and business environment. Looking at Unum U.S. first, we are not seeing any improvement in the natural growth that we have discussed with you over the past several quarters. Our estimate is that natural growth still represents a stubborn habit of approximately 1% today as the economy and specifically, high unemployement and low wage inflation continue to pressure our top line. The highlight we continue to see within Unum U.S. is our success in growing our voluntary benefits business. Sales in this line increased 27% in the third quarter and are now up 17% year-to-date. Having a strong Voluntary Benefits presence is essential to our strategy as we believe our markets will move towards more employee participation in benefit plans and our team is executing very well in this area of growth. 
Within Unum U.K., we are starting to see some stabilization of our premium income. However, we continue to expect to see pressure over the near-term as competitive market conditions persist and economic trends remain challenging in the U.K. Our new sales were somewhat encouraging this quarter. And while they were down 3% in local currency this quarter, the comparison was very difficult given the success we had in the second half of 2009, getting sales as competitive exiting the market. In addition, we are continuing to see a greater portion of sales mix from Group Disability relative to Group Life, which is more in line with the balance that we're looking for. And rounding it out with Colonial Life results, our growth metrics remain in good shape. Third quarter sales increased by 2.3%, less than the rate of growth we experienced in the first half of the year as public sector sales were down on a year-over-year basis, but the Commercial Markets results remained good, with third quarter sales growth of 5.7%. Recruiting trends continue to be strong, with new contracts up 14.2% this quarter and up 19.6% year-to-date. New account growth also remains encouraging, up 10.2% this quarter and 17% for year-to-date. Countering these positive results, our average new case size is lower by 8.8%, driven by the economy and a tendency for our newer agents to have their initial success in the smaller end of the market. With positive sales and recruiting momentum, along with stable persistency trends, Colonial Life's premiums grew 6.2% for the third quarter. 
As you shift to the balance sheet, our investment portfolio continues to be a highlight as we continue to see excellent results in the credit profile of our portfolio. With the rally in the treasury markets during the third quarter, our net unrealized gain position for our fixed maturity securities portfolio, improve further to a quarter end level of $5.1 billion compared to a gain of $3.7 billion at June 30. Net realized investment losses this quarter were insignificant. Importantly, our internal watch list of potential credit  problems in the investment portfolio continues to decline to the point where in aggregate, they sit in an unrealized loss position of less than $5 million. As happy as we are about the strong credit profile, the downside of low interest rates and tightening corporate bond spreads is obviously the challenge equates for new money investment opportunities. And as we had discussed with you in the past, the key focus for our business in this environment is relationship between the portfolio yields, various product lines and the aggregate discount rates embedded in the reserves. For the third quarter, our portfolio of yields held up very well, with our aggregate portfolio of 6.73%, down only 3 basis points from the second quarter of 2010 and down only one basis point from 12/31, 2009 yields. Our individual product line portfolio showed similar results. And although no one sure enjoys this environment, we believe we are relatively well positioned for ongoing low interest rates for a few key reasons. Number one, we have a relatively slow amount of cash to invest in our product lines relative to the size of our existing investment portfolios, which allows our investment team to be very choosy in the assets we take from a relative value perspective. Two, we have maintained a conservative discount rate assumptions while our new money investment opportunities benefited from the wide investment spreads of 2008 in early 2009. Three, we're still putting on nuclear claim reserves each quarter at discount rates lower than the aggregate rate, which will continually lower aggregate discount rate just as lower new money yields will lower the overall portfolio of yield. And lastly, we have the ability to reprice many of our product lines, which allowed us to price for lower interest rates overtime. 
So to sum up, while today's low interest rates are a challenge, I believe we're well-positioned to tolerate this environment. So with solid financial and investment results, book value per share continues to grow. The company's book value per share was $28.08 at September 30, 2010, an increase of 13% relative to a year ago. And looking at our capital, our statutory earnings continue to be quite healthy, which drives a very sound capital position for the company. Net income on a statutory basis for our traditional U.S. life insurance subsidiaries in the third quarter was $148 million, and then with the roughly $150 million we've been generating. This healthy level of earnings resulted in growth in our capital base and insurance subsidiaries and improvement in our RBC ratio to approximately 410%, which is above the range we had set out for ourselves. Holding company cash and marketable securities remains at a very strong level totaling $1.03 billion at quarter end. During the third quarter, we issued $400 million of 10-year senior notes, primarily to fund the payment of a debt maturity of $225 million in the third quarter of 2011. In addition, we have recently used $100 million of the proceeds for an additional pension contribution which occurred in October after the close of the third quarter, and as an acceleration of the pension plan contribution we expected to make in 2011. With the $400 million debt issuance, our leverage ratio is now 23.3%. However, this will decline by approximately 200 basis points as we pay off the debt maturing in the first quarter next year. We also continue to return capital to shareholders by buying back our shares, repurchasing 9.5 million shares in the third quarter. We have been opportunistic in buying back shares when price has been low but this quarter's repurchase was done at an average share price of $20.91. We have approximately $173 million remaining of the $500 million authorized by our board in May. And I'll close with a comment on our outlook for the remainder of 2010. Our outlook a year ago, coming into 2010, was for operating income growth within a range of 4% to 6%. We believe that the lower end of this range is more likely for operating earnings growth in full year 2010, with continued challenges result expected from our U.K. operation near term. However, given our share repurchases, we anticipate operating earnings per share towards the higher end of that target range. We will discuss these, as well as our outlook for 2011, at our investor meeting on November 17. I'll now turn it back to Tom for his closing comments.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. As I said earlier, I continue to be generally pleased with our results. While the economic and competitive conditions remain challenging, we are benefiting from our disciplined, more diversified business model and strong capital position. Wh
componenttext: Thanks, Rick. As I said earlier, I continue to be generally pleased with our results. While the economic and competitive conditions remain challenging, we are benefiting from our disciplined, more diversified business model and strong capital position. While it maybe difficult to see the day, I also think the investments we're making on our businesses today are positioning us well for the future. As Rick said, we look forward to discussing this with you further at our investor day meeting in New York in November and if you haven't already done so, you can register for the meeting through our website or by contacting our Investor Relations office. This concludes our formal comments and Tim, let's move to the question-and-answer session.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Darin Arita with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Darin Arita with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: A question on the RBC ratio. It's up to 410%. How high are you willing to let that increase?
componenttext: A question on the RBC ratio. It's up to 410%. How high are you willing to let that increase?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at the 410%, I think we talked about a range of 335% to 400%. So we're actually above that range today. We're fortunate that statutory earnings have pushed that level but I think it's above the range that we've set out for ourselves already. S
componenttext: If you look at the 410%, I think we talked about a range of 335% to 400%. So we're actually above that range today. We're fortunate that statutory earnings have pushed that level but I think it's above the range that we've set out for ourselves already. So I don't think we'd expect it to go much higher. At the same time, you're seeing us buying back stock and returning capital to our investors at a rate consistent with the earnings the we're generating. So we feel very good about where we are from a capital perspective but we have no desire to let that go further.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So is it fair to assume that the dividends out of insurance should increase and be pretty steady from here?
componenttext: So is it fair to assume that the dividends out of insurance should increase and be pretty steady from here?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's actually been pretty steady and we'll expect those dividends to look similarly. You would note our holding company cash flow so we don't need to take the dividends out but we'd like to keep a very steady operating model of cash upstreaming co
componenttext: I think it's actually been pretty steady and we'll expect those dividends to look similarly. You would note our holding company cash flow so we don't need to take the dividends out but we'd like to keep a very steady operating model of cash upstreaming consistent with the earnings that we're generating in those subsidiaries.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And turning to the U.K., you have Jack there now. He's very well regarded. I guess what are we planning to do differently in the U.K.?
componenttext: And turning to the U.K., you have Jack there now. He's very well regarded. I guess what are we planning to do differently in the U.K.?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could, just to set the stage la little bit and before I ask Jack maybe to make a few comments in his observations. But I think as you and others know, over the last couple of years talking U.K. business. We've talking about the fact that the generous
componenttext: If I could, just to set the stage la little bit and before I ask Jack maybe to make a few comments in his observations. But I think as you and others know, over the last couple of years talking U.K. business. We've talking about the fact that the generous margins that we've been fortunate to be able to experience are probably not sustainable just because they're going to invite competition and as competition comes in, we expect our margins to certainly come down. The other thing we certainly didn't see in the acquisitions and I think that could continue to help support those higher levels of margins. And while we certainly didn't expect was the really venomous level of competitive dynamics that Jack can talk to in that market, nor did we expect the economy to the extent it did. But I think just to set the stage, I thought a change was necessary. It certainly wasn't about the quarter. it wasn't about concerned a business and prices. It was more about just concerned about the speed they which we are addressing the short term issues, which are really more competitive market conditions and economic issues. But then the other part is also the speed by which we are positioning ourselves to benefit from what I think is a tremendous other growth opportunities there. So that's really what's behind the change. You're right, Jack's got a tremendous record from the things that he's done. We have a lot of confidence in business. It's still our highest ROE business as Rick said in his comments. I think Jack has been there since the middle of July. And I think Jack will have a chance to get some pretty good observation on things to share some of those insights.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. Darren, I think the things we're focusing on are really 2-fold. The first is improving our operations. The U.K. is now finding itself operating in a competitive environment that's more similar to the environment that the U.S. is operating
componenttext: Thank you, Tom. Darren, I think the things we're focusing on are really 2-fold. The first is improving our operations. The U.K. is now finding itself operating in a competitive environment that's more similar to the environment that the U.S. is operating in over the last several years. Fortunately, the margins are higher in the U.K. But a lot of the things that you need to do to succeed in the U.K. are similar to the things we did in the U.S. Those would be focusing on pricing and underwriting discipline, make sure we're controlling the rates we're quoting, having milestone sign-offs, increasing the focus of underwriting in sales and profitability, and implementing some of the comprehensive renewal programs that we have in the U.S. here within the U.K. in order to improve margins. We're also  going to bring across a lot of the claims management processes that we've developed over the last couple of years within the U.S. and implement those in the U.K. I'd note that it's a well-worn path that we're implementing. It's something we've done before in the U.S. It's something that I personally was involved in both within underwriting in the claims process. And where we believe that by bringing those best practices over here, we will be able to buck against the competitive headwinds we're facing, continue to get strong margins and continue to improve results. The second piece of that is beyond kind of shoring up the business with operational and financial controls relates to really tapping into the untapped market over here. In the U.K., only one out of 10 employees in the private sector are currently covered for a group income protection. That's probably 70% to 80% in the U.S., Canada and several other developed countries. And so we want to take a good run at expanding that coverage. We think that's a huge growth opportunity within the U.K. The time is ripe, both in terms of what's happening in the government, as well as in employee benefits and we hope to capitalize on that.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We will take our next question from Mark Wilson with Macquarie.
componenttext: We will take our next question from Mark Wilson with Macquarie.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I kind of want to follow-up on that on the U.K., I mean on the one hand, loss ratios were higher, I think probably than most people in this call had expected. But on the other hand, we're still talking about a 20% ROE business. And so I guess the
componenttext: I guess I kind of want to follow-up on that on the U.K., I mean on the one hand, loss ratios were higher, I think probably than most people in this call had expected. But on the other hand, we're still talking about a 20% ROE business. And so I guess the question I have is, one is talked about pricing discipline, is there opportunity to push price given where margins are in the U.K. and given where the competitive landscape is? Is it more driven by claim handling procedure changes or should we be really thinking about this kind of level of loss ratio experience as kind of a new normal?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jack, you've got all those in his mind. Why don't you take that one?
componenttext: Jack, you've got all those in his mind. Why don't you take that one?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I do think prices have eroded in the marketplace over the past 2 years. I think there's recognition in the U.K. that it's been a very soft market and that it's not in the best interest of carriers, intermediaries or anyone to continue in that direction. A
componenttext: I do think prices have eroded in the marketplace over the past 2 years. I think there's recognition in the U.K. that it's been a very soft market and that it's not in the best interest of carriers, intermediaries or anyone to continue in that direction. And so we are the market leader in the U.K. If prices are going to harden in the U.K., we need to participate in that. And so that will be a part of pricing discipline with an attempt to make sure we shore up margins, make sure they don't continue to erode and face pressure from the economy. But doing it in a strategic and really targeted way so that we minimize the impact on our enforced block where we're improving margins. From a claims management perspective, there's a big difference between claims management practices within the U.K. and what we had done within the U.S. My read on that one is kind of why wouldn't you do it? I mean, we have solid practices, we know how to implement it, we're confident that it can improve results. It's a better process both from everyone's perspective, both internally with regulators and with claimants and employers. And so it just makes sense to implement that, and we do believe that our margin in Claims Management relative to competitors is not as wide as it's been in the past. By implementing these practices, we think we can begin to spread that out a little bit and give us more opportunity to grow the market and invest in it.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, if I could add to that. I think that really therefore, we look at the financial results, I think probably the pricing action is more important as you think about financial results. Jack talked about claims improvement, those are certainly the things
componenttext: Mark, if I could add to that. I think that really therefore, we look at the financial results, I think probably the pricing action is more important as you think about financial results. Jack talked about claims improvement, those are certainly the things that we position ourselves in the market, in terms of the quality and consistency of our performance, which we think leverage in terms of growing the market.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess one other question on the discount rate and commentary around portfolio yields which seem to be holding up in the spread to the discount rate, seems pretty healthy above what you target. If rates stayed kind of where we are, at what point would yo
componenttext: I guess one other question on the discount rate and commentary around portfolio yields which seem to be holding up in the spread to the discount rate, seems pretty healthy above what you target. If rates stayed kind of where we are, at what point would you need to make a discount rate change or do we have several quarters for that? It doesn't really come into play?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly have several quarters that doesn't come into play. Maybe you're talking in terms of years, in terms of how that looks. We're getting through this environment very well. I tell you, our investment team has been very opportunistic. So we haven'
componenttext: We certainly have several quarters that doesn't come into play. Maybe you're talking in terms of years, in terms of how that looks. We're getting through this environment very well. I tell you, our investment team has been very opportunistic. So we haven't seen our margins that we talked about or the distance between our asset yields and our discount rates deteriorate at all in this environment. I think we may have lost a couple of basis points related to our disability rates but still, well in excess of our margins. So I don't think we feel under pressure today to do a whole lot of them.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rick, if I can add to. I think actually you made the point in your comment but we don't have a lot to put out, actually. Because we've work very hard from asset liability point of view to make sure we spread out our maturities and measure liabilities very
componenttext: Rick, if I can add to. I think actually you made the point in your comment but we don't have a lot to put out, actually. Because we've work very hard from asset liability point of view to make sure we spread out our maturities and measure liabilities very carefully. I think actually between now and the end of the year, we have about $100 million to put out into the marketplace, which gives you a sense of how little activities having in this environment.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from John Nadel with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from John Nadel with Sterne Agee.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Rick, I wanted to come back to your comments on capital and buybacks for a moment. As we think about excess capital and deployment, is it fair for us to look upon, especially given the risk-based capital ratio and the insurance subs, is it fair for us
componenttext: So Rick, I wanted to come back to your comments on capital and buybacks for a moment. As we think about excess capital and deployment, is it fair for us to look upon, especially given the risk-based capital ratio and the insurance subs, is it fair for us to look upon that $1 billion of cash at the holding company, maybe net of the $225 million debt maturity in March as fully deployable? And if so, what time period should we be looking at in terms of expectations for deploying that capital?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I look at the holding company capital, specifically I think you're right $1 billion, then cut it back to the $225 million, we have effectively prefunded for our maturity coming up in the first quarter and also haircut $100 million off that that we put
componenttext: If I look at the holding company capital, specifically I think you're right $1 billion, then cut it back to the $225 million, we have effectively prefunded for our maturity coming up in the first quarter and also haircut $100 million off that that we put into pension. And so there is excess there. In this environment, we probably still look to around 2x coverage as a holding company, which is quite conservative but probably a good benchmark. 1x coverage is roughly $250 million. So there's still excess there. But think of this very much as a capital run rate generation that we've seen over multiple quarters and returning that capital to shareholders.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So 2x coverage, $500 million, really?
componenttext: So 2x coverage, $500 million, really?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I said it was conservative.
componenttext: Yes. I said it was conservative.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's very conservative. Then I guess, related to excess capital, I guess question on M&A, has there been any pickup in M&A opportunities in the Group Insurance area? I mean given the pressure, I mean we see the pressure from the companies that we active
componenttext: That's very conservative. Then I guess, related to excess capital, I guess question on M&A, has there been any pickup in M&A opportunities in the Group Insurance area? I mean given the pressure, I mean we see the pressure from the companies that we actively cover. But I have to assume there's still many other smaller players out there that must be struggling as well. And in potentially might view the current environment as an opportunity to change their view on what they believe is a core business. Is anything changing along those lines?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the group space, I think people still like the business. It's generating good returns for people so that's the one that people are hanging onto and concentrating on. You see that sometimes in a competitive environment. There are opportuni
componenttext: When you look at the group space, I think people still like the business. It's generating good returns for people so that's the one that people are hanging onto and concentrating on. You see that sometimes in a competitive environment. There are opportunities out there. I think the most important thing is we look at those opportunities. One, we have the capital to transact, we just talked about. But they have to have the right fit. We have to be getting something more. We'll do a financial transaction but it will be with a very high hurdle. But we have to be getting something out of the deal as well. So I tell you, they're still a pretty sparse market in the group space that M&A emanate will be a big part of the growth strategy but we're certainly looking and we're certainly well known out there that we would be a buyer in many situations.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally, I'd be remiss, you guys have probably more this quarter in your prepared remarks than I can recall over the past couple of quarters, the competitive environment, aggressive competition are terms that I think we've heard at least a few ti
componenttext: And then finally, I'd be remiss, you guys have probably more this quarter in your prepared remarks than I can recall over the past couple of quarters, the competitive environment, aggressive competition are terms that I think we've heard at least a few times on this call. Any update you can provide us to where the competitive environment sits, if you think about it relative to last quarter or the quarter before. We're coming up on a very important sales period. What's your expectations around that and terms and conditions, just getting that much more aggressive?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin will speak to the U.S., and maybe Jack, if you could make a couple of comments about the U.K. But Kevin?
componenttext: Kevin will speak to the U.S., and maybe Jack, if you could make a couple of comments about the U.K. But Kevin?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's so much terms and conditions. I think it's flat out price. As I said last quarter common cares are continuing to that if they primarily driven by the fact that they want to maintain level, they want to maintain their organizations an
componenttext: I don't think there's so much terms and conditions. I think it's flat out price. As I said last quarter common cares are continuing to that if they primarily driven by the fact that they want to maintain level, they want to maintain their organizations and without employment economy now turning out in across the board in the industry. As we track pricing levels, using some outside research support, industry pricing levels continue to sort of slide downwards. They haven't flattened but they certainly haven't turned in the other direction. We're entering the 2011 renewal season. We would've expected, maybe based on some comments we've heard in the marketplace, that might be a real easier to play. But we haven't seen that so far. We see competition on business just as aggressively, maybe even more aggressive than in the past couple of years. So bottom line is I'm not seeing any hardening.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of that pricing level sliding downward, can you give a sense as to order of magnitude there?
componenttext: And in terms of that pricing level sliding downward, can you give a sense as to order of magnitude there?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it doesn't really take very much. Maybe down a couple of points with that. But in any given case though, when you've got 4 or 5 carriers bidding, the spread can be quite, not low.
componenttext: I think it doesn't really take very much. Maybe down a couple of points with that. But in any given case though, when you've got 4 or 5 carriers bidding, the spread can be quite, not low.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jack, you want a quick comment in the U.K.?
componenttext: Jack, you want a quick comment in the U.K.?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, within the U.K. I think that there's a lot of pressure. It's a little different. We're 50% of the market in the U.K. If you think about it, our persistency 2009 to 2010 improved during 3.5%. So that puts a lot of pressure on competitors from a pricin
componenttext: Yes, within the U.K. I think that there's a lot of pressure. It's a little different. We're 50% of the market in the U.K. If you think about it, our persistency 2009 to 2010 improved during 3.5%. So that puts a lot of pressure on competitors from a pricing perspective. Anyway, I think there's a lot of pressure on the fourth quarter. Unlike the U.S., the fourth quarter is not a big quarter in the U.K. It's actually April is our biggest renewal month. So it's a little bit different, a little bit delayed. But there are a lot of competitors out there that are starving for sales. We are looking to raise the pricing number a lot. We're probably going to have to suffer a little bit in persistency for that to happen with the expectation that rates will harden certainly in the second half of next year.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Tom Gallagher from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Tom Gallagher from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question is can you talk a bit about statutory earnings trends? Those remained pretty strong. Overall, $600 million sort of annualized, a pretty good run rate here especially as we consider a sustained low rate environment. Is there any stat impact
componenttext: First question is can you talk a bit about statutory earnings trends? Those remained pretty strong. Overall, $600 million sort of annualized, a pretty good run rate here especially as we consider a sustained low rate environment. Is there any stat impact that you would expect to see as a result of low rates or do you think we still see a pretty steady level of earnings power, including in the U.K.? Are you still generating the same level of say cash earnings that you'd be able to take out of the U.K.? That's my first question.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the stat earnings, the generation we saw $150 million. That's still been a very steady run rate. So a lot can happen but we see that very consistently even as we look to the future. Specifically to interest rates, there are impacts that c
componenttext: When you look at the stat earnings, the generation we saw $150 million. That's still been a very steady run rate. So a lot can happen but we see that very consistently even as we look to the future. Specifically to interest rates, there are impacts that can happen with lowering of discount rates on a statutory basis. But we see that baked in to our results and still be able to generate that clean $150 million roughly a quarter. When you look to the U.K. and I think there was earnings there, we'll come down a little bit, commensurately with what you're seeing on the gas side so they will be a little bit lower, earnings run rate that we see in the U.K. but nothing that we're overly concerned about. So if I take you back to slide we're showing in the Investor Day last year, the overall capital generation of the company still is very good and expect that to continue.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Rick, is there any pressure coming from the Long-term Care business in any way, shape or form, whether it's gap or whether it's on statutory financials? And then what subsidiary would the long-term care book or most of it be in a regulatory basis
componenttext: And then Rick, is there any pressure coming from the Long-term Care business in any way, shape or form, whether it's gap or whether it's on statutory financials? And then what subsidiary would the long-term care book or most of it be in a regulatory basis?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The term care book was written for relatively in America. So that's where you would see the LTC business was written. When you look at the pressure there, I don't feel any particular pressure, different than we would have seen years ago when LTC, the indi
componenttext: The term care book was written for relatively in America. So that's where you would see the LTC business was written. When you look at the pressure there, I don't feel any particular pressure, different than we would have seen years ago when LTC, the individual business, which we have stopped writing, is a more challenging business. That's why we're not writing it. So i have a see the trend lines in that business changed very much from what we would've seen over a number of years. So I'd say, no additional pressure we see there.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now, I guess just getting back on the U.K., as we think about that business, is there any risk here of a reserve review, of anything else that we should be aware of from a margin standpoint? I mean it sounds like it's a challenging environment but is it r
componenttext: Now, I guess just getting back on the U.K., as we think about that business, is there any risk here of a reserve review, of anything else that we should be aware of from a margin standpoint? I mean it sounds like it's a challenging environment but is it really just an issue of looking at operating earnings or could there be something beyond that. Whenever I hear situation where things are in flux and restructuring, and to some extent, that's one question that comes up. Can you address sort of that question on the U.K.?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, when you look at the U.K., I'll first start off with the margins, this business is still very high so they're lower than one would have seen but those were off of what would've said and we did say at very lofty levels. So I think at the start there b
componenttext: Yes, when you look at the U.K., I'll first start off with the margins, this business is still very high so they're lower than one would have seen but those were off of what would've said and we did say at very lofty levels. So I think at the start there before we talked about the pressure. As we see the loss ratio creep up into the 60%, 67% range, that's even higher than we would'v seen a quarter ago. So there is pressure than recognizing that a bit more than earnings run rate issue than anything else from a structural perspective. And as Jack mentioned, as he looks in the business and different practices he wants to bring in, there will be some change that goes on there but I don't see anything material on that front.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Jack, just one last for you. I know you talked a bit about best practices on claims handling. If you successfully overlaid your U.S. practices on the U.K. business, are we talking about a 50 basis point improvement on the benefit ratio or 500 basis po
componenttext: And Jack, just one last for you. I know you talked a bit about best practices on claims handling. If you successfully overlaid your U.S. practices on the U.K. business, are we talking about a 50 basis point improvement on the benefit ratio or 500 basis points? Can you help sort of frame what you think the opportunity there would be?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's really hard to predict what the opportunity will be. I think it's pretty clear that we can improve things through increasing the rigor of the practices and I think the appropriate resources on it. There are some differences between the U.S. a
componenttext: I think it's really hard to predict what the opportunity will be. I think it's pretty clear that we can improve things through increasing the rigor of the practices and I think the appropriate resources on it. There are some differences between the U.S. and the U.K. in terms of practices that would make it hard to predict from the U.S. experienced just how much things are going improve in the U.K. We were very optimistic that we can make things better. But I think we'd be reluctant to put a number around what the improvement would be.

componenttext: We will talk about it at Investor Day but I think that was down 3% to 5%, consistent with what we ended up doing here as we authorize a $500 million buyback. We'll obviously talk to our board about what we're going to do. But it all comes back to the earnings generation, such at our earnings and returning that to shareholders. So you put that all back and returning that capital and frustrating shareholder base effectively, we'll generate those kinds of earnings growth rates.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: Chris, I'd like to add too, I think one of the things you can sens is that we're very confident that our business model is capable of producing much more consistent results, including statutory results. And I think Rick touched on it when you have that consistent delivery of statutory results, that makes it available free cash flow, which have a lot of choice in terms of how you put that cash flow to work. To my second point, if you look at the last 3 years, we have to be one of the only companies that have now fared really aggressively on share buybacks as, well as dividend increases, think this is part of our MRO going forward.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: One follow-up question in terms of the Group Disability side at Unum U.S, a number of the larger competitors people talk about adverse loss experience and are beginning to talk about taking rate increases? Would you expect that some of these plans are shopped around? You maybe get some more looks than you've gotten in the past or do you think the business is just way too low to begin with that even mid-single-digit price increases doesn't make the risk appropriate?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We will do a lot more looks than one in the past but as the market share leader, we tend to get pretty much all the looks that are out there. We've got the broadest field in wholesale and retail distribution system out there as well. But I think if compet
componenttext: We will do a lot more looks than one in the past but as the market share leader, we tend to get pretty much all the looks that are out there. We've got the broadest field in wholesale and retail distribution system out there as well. But I think if competitors start to raise rates in this economy, I think it would be good for stabilizing the risk environment and I think that the quality of our field force and the diversity of our portfolio would probably would see some benefit from that, yes.

componenttext: Two questions. First, I wanted to go back to U.K. and the comment that the U.K. is looking more like the U.S. but still higher margins, can you give us some sense of where you think the U.K. ROE normalizes? And then I have one follow-up.

componenttext: Yes. I think our expedition right now, given the look of the margins that were we are, it is certainly over the long-term we don't expect any further deterioration in the ROE so we would peg it at that 20%, which is where it is now, with some optimism around these this pricing changes that the market does react to that, as well as if we can get some footholds in the claim processing changes. We think there are opportunities to improve it.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the question would be that doesn't sound like it looks very much like the U.S.
componenttext: I guess the question would be that doesn't sound like it looks very much like the U.S.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was talking about the U.S. in terms of the erosion of margins and the level of competitiveness as opposed to the absolute level of margins. The absolute level continues to be significantly higher. It started from a much higher level than the U.S. did. I
componenttext: I was talking about the U.S. in terms of the erosion of margins and the level of competitiveness as opposed to the absolute level of margins. The absolute level continues to be significantly higher. It started from a much higher level than the U.S. did. It's a much narrower market than the U.S, so my comments were more from a relative perspective to where it had been historically as opposed to comparing margins in the U.S. and the U.K because they are much stronger, have always been much stronger and would expect to continue that way.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: Jack also speaks to a lot of the operational efficiencies we can get by using this practices from the U.S., maybe more aggressively in the U.K. That's also a source of value including the fact that we're rolling out a new offering that's very similar to Simply Unum. As you know, we rolled it out about a year and a half ago here in the U.S. We're rolling that out in the U.K. actually get as much. So the other part of it is just the leveraging of the core capabilities that we have that are proven elsewhere and maybe more quickly accelerate the usage of those in the U.K. as well.

componenttext: It's significantly more concentrated. They are basically 4 players in the group income protection market. There's the life of Aviva and LNG. Dingoes for players of commerce and 80% of the market over year.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: And then just a question on capital for Rick, if you look at other, I would say, well-run disability companies or group insurance companies, StanCorp talks about an RBC target of 300%. I understand your business is different. You have the U.K. piece but I'm curious why 375% to 400% RBC plus 2x holding company requirements isn't an excessively conservative level of capital?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: When we look at the level of capital that we're holding, I think it's trying to be reflective of the environment. I think some of our peers mentioned are running at higher levels as well. They just haven't changed the benchmarks. I think what we're trying
componenttext: When we look at the level of capital that we're holding, I think it's trying to be reflective of the environment. I think some of our peers mentioned are running at higher levels as well. They just haven't changed the benchmarks. I think what we're trying to say is we want or flight the environment. So in a more difficult environment. While to find that on a couple of fronts. One would be what we see in the economy still, which is challenging. You can see that in unemployment and wage rules. You can also see it in terms of the dynamic regulatory environment that we see around us. I think being be a little bit more conservative make sense. Do we need to hold there? Is it than a level expect the company to run on going forward? Probably not. But it today's environments those are the levels we think are dictated by this environment that we're in.

componenttext: I'll probably give you the specifics on that but it's going to be lower than we're running the company at today for that exact reason that we're running excesses ready with axis given the environment around us to go that is on our long-term expectation of the capital we had. componenttext: Yes, my sense of the benefit ratio is certainly the level of deterioration while slow. Our opinions have begun to level out over the last couple of quarters. That's been a factor in the benefit ratio. Depending on what happens, I think we might see some pressure for the next couple of quarters. But I would expect beyond that, that by the second half of next year, we would have stabilized and begun to improve it.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: In good long-term care first of all, we continue to be in that market. But it's a valuable part of our portfolio consistent with the progress that we do Voluntary Benefits would. And it's very consistent with our strategy. Much of our group Long-term Care business includes employer funding. The average age is workforce in the mid-40s. That said, we have the ability to reprice group Long-term Care because it has approved products and we continue to evaluate sort of over the course of time, what the right level of pricing is and how do we make sure that that pricing matches up with the interest rate environment in particular. But in terms of operational experience, group long-term care has performed quite well. On the individual side, we're no longer writing business. We're in the process of looking at what kind of rate increase would be necessary to show up that book of business and we'll be rolling that through a number of discussions with state regulators over the next several weeks and then we'll have more to report in a few weeks.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: One follow up, I didn't want to leave Randy out of this. The persistency at Colonial, I think hit record levels across the board. What's working so well for Colonial that doesn't seem to be working for some of your other competitors?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a long answer, Colin. We're just focused on the basics, with our fieldforce. We're really emphasizing the service side of our business and getting our agents back out to visit our enforced customers. And spending time with them doing benefits couns
componenttext: That's a long answer, Colin. We're just focused on the basics, with our fieldforce. We're really emphasizing the service side of our business and getting our agents back out to visit our enforced customers. And spending time with them doing benefits counseling. And in many cases, that doesn't add to sales and in many others, it does, but at least gets our folks out in front of our existing customers and we're staying after that and even having steady and even improving persistency results as you point out. So I think it just comes back to a strong area focus for us.

componenttext: I was actually going to ask about colonial, too and I guess Colin just hit on it. componenttext: I sure am, Tom. I think the answer there is really intertwined for both sides of that. We are very focused on growing our agency distribution system. We continue to have very good results there quarter-over-quarter. We're up near 20% on a year-to-date basis in terms of new rep contracts. And we're working very hard to make more and more of those folks productive as early as possible. And so I think it's just a matter focus and consistency there. And that's also helping us then with our overall sales increase for the year and we're getting a considerable lift in production from reps we've brought on over the last 2 to 3 years and that's a real difference maker for us in this very tough economic environment.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: Does that help you recruit? Because I guess that other folks in this area are just having trouble getting sales folks in the door and other smaller franchises out there. Just trying to understand going well.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: It's a success and more people wanting to come on board and we're getting a lot of referrals for new agents from people that have joined us in the last couple of years. And it just snowballs in a very positive way for us.

componenttext: This is actually Ryan Krueger for Jeff. I had a high-level question on operating earnings trends. If we just look at recent sequential numbers, the total operating earnings are 229 in the second quarter, 220 in the third and I think guidance implied 215 range in the fourth quarter. So sequential decline in trend in recent quarters and I'm curious when we look at 2011 given the pressures on the top line. Is that a trend that you think of stabilize or should we expect earnings to continue to decline somewhat on a sequential basis based on the top line pressures?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: It's a good lead in to our investment day, which I'll reiterate is on November 17 but just to give you the high level, I think those flattening trends are something that you've seen from the operating earnings. It's certainly being offset by a lot of the share repurchase we've been able to do our EPS growing quite nicely and we'll give you some more insight into 2011. I think we've seen good results in 2010, consistent with the way we laid it out in the 4% 6% range and we look at 2011 with a similar view.
