And finally, with our solid financial results and strong investment performance, we continue to build on our very strong capital position. Our weighted average risk-based capital ratio is currently at 410%, and our holding company's cash and marketable securities position is slightly above $1 billion, giving us continued financial flexibility in these uncertain times. We have built these strong capital levels while also purchasing $198 million of stock during the third quarter and $328 million of stock year-to-date.
In summary, I feel very good about our results so far this year. I think the diversity of our company is becoming more apparent. The relatively strong performance of Unum US and Colonial Life operations offset the lower level of performance in the UK. As you know, we've made a management change there, and I'm confident that under Jack McGarry's leadership, we can continue to -- we can more effectively operate in this difficult market environment and capitalize on the growth opportunities which I believe exist in this market. 
While we continue to face premium growth challenges in certain lines of business, we continue to benefit from our disciplined business approach, which has allowed us to generate capital that can be used to repurchase stock at a very opportune time. 
Now I'll ask Tom White to provide an overview on our operating results this quarter. Tom?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Tom. Net income for the third quarter was $220.8 million or $0.68 per diluted common share, compared to net income of $221.1 million or $0.66 per diluted common share last year. Included in the results for the third quarter of 2010 are net
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Tom. Net income for the third quarter was $220.8 million or $0.68 per diluted common share, compared to net income of $221.1 million or $0.66 per diluted common share last year. Included in the results for the third quarter of 2010 are net realized after-tax investment gains of $0.9 million or less than $0.01 per diluted common share, compared to net realized after-tax gains of $9.5 million or $0.02 per diluted common share, in the third quarter of 2009. 
Net realized after-tax investment gains for the third quarter of 2010 include an after-tax gain of $1.1 million resulting from changes in the fair value of an embedded derivative and a modified coinsurance contract, compared to an after-tax gain of $28.9 million in the third quarter of 2009. Also included in net realized after-tax investment gains for the third quarter are net realized after-tax investment losses of $200,000 related to sales and write-downs of investments, compared to net after-tax losses of $19.4 million in the third quarter of 2009. Excluding these items, after-tax operating income was $219.9 million for this quarter or $0.68 per diluted common share, compared to $211.6 million or $0.64 per diluted common share in the year-ago quarter.
Turning to the operating segments. In total, Unum US operating income increased 4% to $204.7 million in the third quarter. Within Unum US, the group disability line reported another solid quarter, with income up 4% to $77.8 million, driven primarily by improved risk experience on a year-over-year basis. Within the group lines and AD&D line, operating income increased 6% to $52.8 million in the third quarter. A slight improvement in premium income as well as stable risk experience helped to generate the improved earnings.
In the supplemental and voluntary line, third quarter income was up 2.8% to $74.1 million from $72.1 million a year ago. The improvement was driven by strong earnings growth from the voluntary benefits line of business. 
Moving to Unum UK, operating income in this segment decreased $19.6 million to $47.2 million. Operating income declined 15.1% in local currency. While premium income in local currency was essentially flat in the third quarter, the benefit ratio of 66.9% was well above the unusually low benefit ratio of the year-ago quarter. You'll recall that the third quarter of 2009 benefit ratio benefited from a reserve reduction associated with a significant reduction in the value of inflation index-linked policies. This reduction in reserves was largely offset by a corresponding reduction in net investment income on index-linked securities. The year-over-year reduction in income reflects pressure from the economic environment on our ability to resolve claims and continued competitive pricing pressures, particularly in the group disability lines.
Concluding our core operations, Colonial Life had a strong quarter, with premium growth of 6.2% and operating income growth of 5.8% compared to last year. The benefit ratio was 49.9% this quarter compared with a year-ago benefit ratio of 48.2%, but in line with our longer-term expectations for this business segment.
The Individual Disability — Closed Block operating income was $9.8 million compared to $7.2 million in the year-ago quarter. The interest adjusted loss ratio was higher at 85.5% this quarter compared to 81.6% in the year-ago quarter, but was consistent with the second quarter of 2010.  Premium income declined by 6%, and net investment income was up 1% year-over-year. 
And finally, the Corporate and Other segment reported an operating loss of $10.8 million compared to a loss of $13.7 million in the year-ago quarter. Net investment income was higher, reflecting higher levels of invested assets and higher miscellaneous net investment income, while interest expense increased to $31.8 million this year compared to $24.1 million last year, reflecting the debt issuances from September of 2009 and September of 2010.
So with that review of our operating results, I'll turn the call over to Rick McKenney for a deeper analysis of this quarter's results.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. In my comments, I'd like to discuss this quarter's key drivers, which have remained relatively consistent, and also cover our investment portfolio, interest rate management and our capital position. First, starting on how risk is performin
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. In my comments, I'd like to discuss this quarter's key drivers, which have remained relatively consistent, and also cover our investment portfolio, interest rate management and our capital position. First, starting on how risk is performing, across the company it is generally stable, with some pockets of elevated experience off of last year's very favorable results. 
Focusing on Unum US, risk experience remained generally stable across all lines this quarter. Our group disability results remained strong with a third quarter benefit ratio of 84.6%, lower than the year-ago quarter experience of 85.3% due to more favorable claim recovery performance and flat with the benefit ratio in the second quarter. New claim incidence for the quarter was consistent with the year-ago experience but slightly elevated relative to the second quarter. The claim incidence trends are not showing notable underlying trends or any signs of being economically influenced. 
This quarter's results also reflect our view that our group disability benefit ratio will level out this year and that longer-term opportunities for improvement can be achieved gradually as our core market exposure changes with our inforce mix of business. I would note that given today's challenging environment, I believe our current pretax margin of 15% and ROE of 12.6% for the third quarter for the group disability business line are quite strong.
Also within Unum US, group life and AD&D experience remained very steady, with the third quarter benefit ratio at 70.4% compared to 70.3% in the year-ago quarter and second quarter as well. Finally, the voluntary and supplemental lines showed favorable claims experience in the voluntary benefit line, with third quarter benefit ratio declining to 54.6% from 59% a year ago, offset by a slightly higher benefit ratio in the individual disability recently issued line due to higher average size of new claims. The long term care line showed generally steady interest adjusted loss ratios of 80.9% in the third quarter compared to 80.8% in the second quarter, and up from 77.5% in the year-ago quarter. 
Moving to our Unum UK results, risk results were worse than last year and up slightly sequentially, with a third quarter 2010 benefit ratio at 66.9%. Weaker results have a number of drivers, including lower net claim resolutions and continued competitive pricing pressures in the group disability line, which is only partially offset by a slight improvement in group life experience. The impact of inflation on the inflation index-linked group policies is generally a non-economic influence and was a significant contributor to the year-ago year-over-year change in the benefit ratio, but had minimal impact on the sequential quarter results. 
The competitive market conditions are negatively impacting our margins in the U.K., and we expect this drag to continue for the near term. I'll remind you that the Unum UK pretax margin was 29% and ROE was nearly 21% this quarter, still a very healthy level of profitability. 
And finally, Colonial Life's risk result this quarter was somewhat unfavorable in the accidents, sickness and disability line of business and drove the benefit ratio for the quarter to just under 50% compared to 48.2% in the year-ago quarter. As we have mentioned before, we believe that the benefit ratio of around 50% is likely an ongoing expectation for Colonial Life as a whole.
Turning to the premium line, the challenges continue in today's economic and business environment. Looking at Unum US first, we are not seeing any improvement in the natural growth that we have discussed with you over the past several quarters. Our estimate is that natural growth still represents a stubborn headwind of approximately 1% today, as the economy and, specifically, high unemployment and low wage inflation continue to pressure our top line. 
The highlight we continue to see within Unum US is our success in growing our voluntary benefits business. Sales in this line increased 27% in the third quarter and are now up 17% year-to-date. Having a strong voluntary benefits presence is essential to our strategy, as we believe our markets will move towards more employee participation in benefit plans, and our team is executing very well in this area of growth.
Within Unum UK, we are starting to see some stabilization of our premium income. However, we continue to expect to see pressure over the near-term as competitive market conditions persist and economic trends remain challenging in the U.K. Our new sales were somewhat encouraging this quarter. And while they were down 3% in local currency this quarter, the comparison was very difficult given the success we had in the second half of 2009, gaining sales as a competitor was exiting the market. In addition, we are continuing to see a greater portion of our sales mix from group disability relative to group life, which is more in line with the balance that we're looking for. 
And rounding it out with Colonial Life results, our growth metrics remain in good shape. Third quarter sales increased by 2.3%, less than the rate of growth we experienced in the first half of the year as public sector sales were down on a year-over-year basis, but the commercial markets' results remained good, with third quarter sales growth of 5.7%. Recruiting trends continue to be strong, with new contracts up 14.2% this quarter and up 19.6% year-to-date. 
New account growth also remains encouraging, up 10.2% this quarter and 17% for year-to-date. Countering these positive results, our average new case size is lower by 8.8%, driven by the economy and the tendency for our newer agents to have their initial success in the smaller end of the market. With positive sales and recruiting momentum, along with stable persistency trends, Colonial Life's premium grew 6.2% for the third quarter. 
As you shift to the balance sheet, our investment portfolio continues to be a highlight as we continue to see excellent results in the credit profile of our portfolio. With a rally in the Treasury markets during the third quarter, our net unrealized gain position for our fixed maturity securities portfolio improved further to a quarter end level of $5.1 billion compared to a gain of $3.7 billion at June 30. Net realized investment losses this quarter were insignificant. Importantly, our internal watch list of potential credit problems in the investment portfolio continues to decline to the point where, in aggregate, they sit in an unrealized loss position of less than $5 million. 
As happy as we are about the strong credit profile, the downside of low interest rates and tiny corporate bond spreads is obviously the challenge it creates for new money investment opportunities. As we have discussed with you in the past, the key focus for our business in this environment is the relationship between the portfolio yields backing our various product lines and the aggregate discount rates embedded in the reserves. For the third quarter, our portfolio yields held up very well, with our aggregate portfolio yield of 6.73% down only 3 basis points from the second quarter of 2010 and down only 1 basis point from 12/31/2009 yields. Our individual product line portfolios showed similar results.
And although no insurer enjoys this environment, we believe we are relatively well positioned for ongoing low interest rates for a few key reasons. Number one, we have a relatively small amount of new cash to invest in our product lines relative to the size of our existing investment portfolios, which allows our investment team to be very choosy in the assets we take from a relative-value perspective. Two, we have maintained a conservative discount rate assumptions, while our new money investment opportunities benefited from the wide investment spreads of 2008 and early 2009. Three, we're still putting on new claim reserves each quarter at discount rates lower than the aggregate rate, which will continually lower our aggregate discount rate, just as lower new money yields will lower the overall portfolio yield. And lastly, we have the ability to reprice many of our product lines, which allows us to price for lower interest rates over time. So to sum up, while today's low interest rates are a challenge, I believe we are well positioned to tolerate this environment.
So with solid financial and investment results, book value per share continues to grow. The company's book value per share was $28.08 at September 30, 2010, an increase of 13% relative to a year ago. And looking at our capital, our statutory earnings continue to be quite healthy, which drives a very sound capital position for the company. Net income on a statutory basis for our traditional U.S. life insurance subsidiaries in the third quarter was $148 million, in line with the roughly $150 million we've been generating. This healthy level of earnings resulted in growth in our capital base at our insurance subsidiaries and improvement in our RBC ratio to approximately 410%, which is above the range we have set out for ourselves. 
Holding company cash and marketable securities remains at a very strong level, totaling $1.03 billion at quarter end. During the third quarter, we issued $400 million of 10-year senior notes, primarily to fund the payment of a debt maturity of $225 million in the first quarter of 2011. In addition, we have recently used $100 million of the proceeds for an additional pension contribution, which occurred in October after the close of the third quarter, and it is an acceleration of the pension plan contribution we expected to make in 2011. 
With the $400 million debt issuance, our leverage ratio is now 23.3%. However, this will decline by approximately 200 basis points as we pay off the debt maturing in the first quarter next year. We also continue to return capital to shareholders by buying back our shares, repurchasing 9.5 million shares in the third quarter. We have been opportunistic in buying back shares when the price has been low, but this quarter's repurchase is done at an average share price of $20.91. We have approximately $173 million remaining of the $500 million authorized by our board in May. 
And I'll close with a comment on our outlook for the remainder of 2010. Our outlook a year ago, coming into 2010, was for operating income growth within a range of 4% to 6%. We believe that the lower end of this range is more likely for operating earnings growth for the full year 2010, with continued challenges result -- continued challenging results expected from our U.K. operation in the near term. However, given our share repurchases, we anticipate operating earnings per share towards the higher end of that target range. We will discuss this, as well as our outlook for 2011, at our investor meeting on November 17. And now I'll turn it back to Tom for his closing comments.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. As I said earlier, I continue to generally be pleased with our results. While the economic and competitive conditions remain challenging, we are benefiting from our disciplined, more diversified business model and strong capital position. Wh
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. As I said earlier, I continue to generally be pleased with our results. While the economic and competitive conditions remain challenging, we are benefiting from our disciplined, more diversified business model and strong capital position. While it may be difficult to see today, I also think the investments we're making in our businesses today are positioning us well for the future. 
As Rick said, we look forward to discussing this with you further at our Investor Day meeting in New York in November, and if you haven't already done so, you can register for the meeting through our website or by contacting our Investor Relations office. 
This completes our formal comments. And, Tim, let's move to the question-and-answer session.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Darin Arita with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Darin Arita with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: A question on the RBC ratio. It's up to 410%. How high are you willing to let that increase to?
componenttext: A question on the RBC ratio. It's up to 410%. How high are you willing to let that increase to?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rick?
componenttext: Rick?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the 410%, I think we talked about a range of 375% to 400%, so we're actually above that range today. We're fortunate that statutory earnings have pushed to that level, but I think it's above the range that we've set out for ourselves alre
componenttext: When you look at the 410%, I think we talked about a range of 375% to 400%, so we're actually above that range today. We're fortunate that statutory earnings have pushed to that level, but I think it's above the range that we've set out for ourselves already. So I don't think we'd expect it to go much higher. At the same time, you're seeing us buying back stock and returning capital to our investors at a rate consistent with the earnings that we're generating. So we feel very good about where we are from a capital perspective, but we have no desire to let that grow further.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So is it fair to assume that the dividends out of the insurance subs should increase and be pretty steady from here?
componenttext: So is it fair to assume that the dividends out of the insurance subs should increase and be pretty steady from here?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's actually been pretty steady, and we'll expect those dividends to look similar. You would note our holding company cash level, so we don't need to take the dividends out. But we'd like to keep a very steady operating model of cash upstream-ing
componenttext: I think it's actually been pretty steady, and we'll expect those dividends to look similar. You would note our holding company cash level, so we don't need to take the dividends out. But we'd like to keep a very steady operating model of cash upstream-ing, consistent with the earnings that we're generating in our subsidiaries.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And turning to the U.K., you have Jack there now. He's very well regarded. I guess, what are we planning to do differently in the U.K.?
componenttext: Okay, great. And turning to the U.K., you have Jack there now. He's very well regarded. I guess, what are we planning to do differently in the U.K.?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. If I could, Darin, let me just sort of set the stage a little bit before I ask Jack maybe to make a few comments on his observations. But I think, as you and others know, for the last couple of years as we've been talking our U.K. business, we've bee
componenttext: Yes. If I could, Darin, let me just sort of set the stage a little bit before I ask Jack maybe to make a few comments on his observations. But I think, as you and others know, for the last couple of years as we've been talking our U.K. business, we've been talking about the fact that the generous margins that we've been so fortunate to be able to experience are probably not sustainable, just because they're going to invite competition. And as competition comes in, we expected our margins to certainly come down. The other thing, too, is we certainly didn't see any acquisitions that I think that could continue to help support those higher levels of margins. And what we certainly didn't expect was the really venomous level of competitive dynamics that Jack can talk to in that market, nor did we expect the economy obviously to soften to the extent it did. But I think just to set the stage for why I thought a change was necessary, it certainly wasn't about a quarter. It wasn't about a feeling or concerned about our business and prices. It was more about just concerned about the speed by which we are addressing the short-term issues, which are really more competitive market conditions and economic issues. But then the other part is also the speed by which we are positioning ourselves to benefit from what I think is a tremendous set of growth opportunities there. So that's really what's behind the change. You're right; Jack's got a tremendous track record in the things that he's done. We have a lot of confidence in that business. It's still our highest ROE business, as Rick said in his comments. And I think, as you know, Jack has been there since really the middle of July. And I think, Jack, you've had a chance to get some pretty good observations on things, and maybe I'll just turn it to you just to share some of those insights.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you, Tom. Darin, I think the things we're focusing on are really 2-fold. The first is improving our operations. The U.K. is now finding itself operating in a competitive environment that's more similar to the environment that the U.S. has opera
componenttext: Yes, thank you, Tom. Darin, I think the things we're focusing on are really 2-fold. The first is improving our operations. The U.K. is now finding itself operating in a competitive environment that's more similar to the environment that the U.S. has operated in over the last several years. Fortunately, the margins are higher in the U.K., but a lot of the things that you need to do to succeed in the U.K. are similar to the things we did in the U.S. Those would be focusing on pricing and underwriting discipline; make sure we're controlling the rates we're quoting; having milestone sign-offs; increasing the focus of underwriting in sales on profitability; and implementing some of the comprehensive renewal programs that we had in the U.S., here within the U.K. in order to improve margins. We're also going to bring across a lot of the claims management processes that we've developed over the last couple of years within the U.S. and implement those in the U.K. I'd note that it's a well-worn path that we're implementing. It's something we've done before in the U.S. It's something that I personally was involved in, both within underwriting and the claims process. And where we believe that by bringing those best practices over here, we will be able to buck against the competitive headwinds we're facing, continue to get strong margins and continue to improve results. The second piece of that, though, beyond kind of shoring up the business with operational and financial controls, relates to really tapping into the untapped market over here. In the U.K., only 1 out of 10 employees in the private sector are currently covered for group income protection. That's probably 70% to 80% in the U.S., Canada and several other developed countries. And so we want to take a good run at expanding that coverage. We think that's a huge growth opportunity within the U.K. The time is ripe, both in terms of what's happening in the government as well as in employee benefits. And we hope to capitalize on that.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Mark Finkelstein with Macquarie.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Mark Finkelstein with Macquarie.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jack, I know you've got all those in your mind. Why don't you take that one?
componenttext: Jack, I know you've got all those in your mind. Why don't you take that one?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. I do think prices have eroded in the marketplace over the past 2 years. I think there's recognition in the U.K. that it's been a very soft market and that it's not in the best interest of carriers, intermediaries or anyone to continue in that direct
componenttext: Okay. I do think prices have eroded in the marketplace over the past 2 years. I think there's recognition in the U.K. that it's been a very soft market and that it's not in the best interest of carriers, intermediaries or anyone to continue in that direction. And so we are the market leader in the U.K. If prices are going to harden in the U.K., we need to participate in that. And so that will be a part of pricing discipline with an attempt to make sure we shore up margins, make sure they don't continue to erode and face pressure from the economy, but do it in a strategic and really targeted way so that we minimize the impact on our inforce block while we're improving margins. From a claims management perspective, there's a big difference between claims management practices within the U.K. and what we had done within the U.S. My read on that one is kind of a "Why wouldn't you do it?" I mean, we have solid practices. We know how to implement it. We're confident that it can improve results. It's a better process both from everyone's perspective, both internally with regulators and with claimants and employers. And so it just makes sense to implement that. And we do believe our margin in claims management relative to competitors is not as wide as it's been in the past. By implementing these practices, we think we can begin to spread that out a little bit and give us more opportunity to grow the market and invest in it.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Mark, if I could add to that, I think that really, therefore, when you look at the financial results, I think probably the pricing actions are the more important as you think about financial results. I think when Jack talked about claims improvement,
componenttext: And Mark, if I could add to that, I think that really, therefore, when you look at the financial results, I think probably the pricing actions are the more important as you think about financial results. I think when Jack talked about claims improvement, those are certainly the things that are going to continue, to be sure that we position ourselves in the market in terms of the quality and consistency of our performance, which we think has a leverage in terms of growing the market.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rick?
componenttext: Rick?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we certainly have several quarters that doesn't come into play. I mean, maybe even talking in terms of years in terms of how that looks. We're getting through this environment very well. I tell you, our investment team is being very opportunistic. So
componenttext: Yes, we certainly have several quarters that doesn't come into play. I mean, maybe even talking in terms of years in terms of how that looks. We're getting through this environment very well. I tell you, our investment team is being very opportunistic. So we haven't seen our margin that we talk about or the distance between our asset yields and our discount rates deteriorate at all in this environment. I think we may have lost a couple of basis points related to our disability rates, but still well in excess of our margins. So I don't think we feel under pressure today to do a whole lot on that front.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rick, if I can add too, I think, actually, just to get a -- you made the point in your comments, but we don't have a lot to put out, actually. And it's because, again, we've work very hard from an asset liability point of view to be sure that we spread ou
componenttext: Rick, if I can add too, I think, actually, just to get a -- you made the point in your comments, but we don't have a lot to put out, actually. And it's because, again, we've work very hard from an asset liability point of view to be sure that we spread out our maturities and match our liabilities very carefully. I think, actually, between now and the end of the year, we only have -- we have about $100 million to put out into the marketplace, which just gives you a sense as to how little investment activity is really happening in this environment.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from John Nadel with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from John Nadel with Sterne Agee.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Rick, I wanted to come back to your comments on capital and buybacks for a moment. As we think about excess capital and deployment, is it fair for us to look upon -- especially given the risk-based capital ratio at the insurance subs, is it fair to us
componenttext: So Rick, I wanted to come back to your comments on capital and buybacks for a moment. As we think about excess capital and deployment, is it fair for us to look upon -- especially given the risk-based capital ratio at the insurance subs, is it fair to us to look upon that $1 billion of cash at the holding company, maybe net of the $225 million debt maturity in March, as fully deployable? And if so, what time period should we be looking at in terms of expectations for deploying that capital?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. If I looked at the holding company capital specifically, I think you're right to take that $1 billion, haircut it back with the $225 million we have effectively prefunded for our maturity coming up in the first quarter. And also, haircut $100 million
componenttext: Yes. If I looked at the holding company capital specifically, I think you're right to take that $1 billion, haircut it back with the $225 million we have effectively prefunded for our maturity coming up in the first quarter. And also, haircut $100 million off of that, that we put into the pension [indiscernible] year. And so there is excess there. In this environment, we probably would still look to around 2x coverage as a holding company, which is quite conservative but probably a good benchmark. 1x coverage is roughly $250 million, so there's still excess there. But think of this very much as a capital run rate generation that we've seen over multiple quarters and returning that capital to shareholders.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So 2x coverage, $500 million? Really?
componenttext: Okay. So 2x coverage, $500 million? Really?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Wow. Okay.
componenttext: Wow. Okay.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I said that was conservative. Well, it is very conservative.
componenttext: I said that was conservative. Well, it is very conservative.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's very conservative. And then, I guess, related to excess capital, I guess a question on M&A. Has there been any pickups in M&A opportunities in the group insurance area? I mean, given the pressure -- I mean, we see the pressure from the companies th
componenttext: That's very conservative. And then, I guess, related to excess capital, I guess a question on M&A. Has there been any pickups in M&A opportunities in the group insurance area? I mean, given the pressure -- I mean, we see the pressure from the companies that we actively cover. But I have to assume there's so many other smaller players out there that must be struggling as well and potentially might view the current environment as an opportunity to change their view on what they believe is a core business. I mean, is anything changing along those lines?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you look at the group space, I think people still like the business. It's generating good returns for people, so that's the one that people are hanging on to and concentrating on. You see that sometimes in the competitive environment. There are oppor
componenttext: When you look at the group space, I think people still like the business. It's generating good returns for people, so that's the one that people are hanging on to and concentrating on. You see that sometimes in the competitive environment. There are opportunities out there. And I think the most important thing as we look at those opportunities -- one, we have the capital to transact, we just talked about, but they have to have the right fit. We have to be getting something more. We'll do a financial transaction, but it will be with a very high hurdle. But we have to be getting something out of that deal as well. So I'd tell you that it's still a pretty sparse market in the group space, that M&A will be a big part of the growth strategy. But we're certainly looking, and we're certainly well known out there that we would be a buyer in many situations.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then finally, I'd be remiss. You guys have -- probably more this quarter in your prepared remarks than I can recall over the past couple of quarters, the competitive environment, the aggressive competition are terms that I think we've heard at l
componenttext: Okay. And then finally, I'd be remiss. You guys have -- probably more this quarter in your prepared remarks than I can recall over the past couple of quarters, the competitive environment, the aggressive competition are terms that I think we've heard at least a few times on this call. Any update you can provide as to where the competitive environment sits? If you think about it relative to last quarter, the quarter before, I mean, we're coming off on a very important sales period. What's your expectations around that? Are terms and conditions just getting that much more aggressive?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, maybe we'll ask Kevin to speak to the U.S., and maybe Jack, if you could make a couple of comments about the U.K. But Kevin?
componenttext: John, maybe we'll ask Kevin to speak to the U.S., and maybe Jack, if you could make a couple of comments about the U.K. But Kevin?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think it's so much terms and conditions. I think it's flat out price. As I said last quarter, incumbent carriers, inforce carriers are continuing to defend their inforce blocks, I think primarily driven by the fact that they want to maintain their
componenttext: I don't think it's so much terms and conditions. I think it's flat out price. As I said last quarter, incumbent carriers, inforce carriers are continuing to defend their inforce blocks, I think primarily driven by the fact that they want to maintain their in-premium levels, they want to maintain their field service organizations. And this has been -- with outlook on employment or the economy not turning around, new sales are just down across the board in the industry. As we track pricing levels using some outside research support, industry pricing levels continue to sort of slide downward. They haven't flattened, and they certainly haven't turned in the other direction. We're entering the 2011 renewal season. We would've expected, maybe based on some comments we've heard in the marketplace, that renewals might be easier to place. But we haven't seen that so far. We see competition on business that we're putting out to renew just as aggressively, maybe even more aggressive than it's been in the past couple of years. So bottom line is I'm not seeing any hardening.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of that pricing level sliding downward, can you give a sense as to order of magnitude there?
componenttext: And in terms of that pricing level sliding downward, can you give a sense as to order of magnitude there?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Oh, I think in this economy, it doesn't really take very much. It might be sliding down a couple of points, something like that. But on any given case though, when you've got 4 or 5 carriers bidding, the spread can be quite wide between high and low.
componenttext: Oh, I think in this economy, it doesn't really take very much. It might be sliding down a couple of points, something like that. But on any given case though, when you've got 4 or 5 carriers bidding, the spread can be quite wide between high and low.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jack, you want to make a quick comment on the U.K.?
componenttext: Jack, you want to make a quick comment on the U.K.?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Within the U.K., I think that there's a lot of pressure. It's a little different. We're 50% of the market in the U.K. If you think about it, our persistency 2009 to 2010 improved 3.5%. So that puts a lot of pressure on competitors from a pricing pers
componenttext: Yes. Within the U.K., I think that there's a lot of pressure. It's a little different. We're 50% of the market in the U.K. If you think about it, our persistency 2009 to 2010 improved 3.5%. So that puts a lot of pressure on competitors from a pricing perspective anyway. I think there's a lot of pressure on the fourth quarter. Unlike the U.S., the fourth quarter is not the big quarter in the U.K. It's actually April is our biggest renewal month. So it's a little bit different, a little bit delayed. But there is a -- there are a lot of competitors out there that are starving for sales. We are looking to raise the pricing umbrella. We're probably going to have to suffer a little bit in persistency for that to happen, with the expectation that rates will harden certainly in the second half of next year.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Tom Gallagher with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Tom Gallagher with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question is, can you talk a bit about statutory earnings trends? Those have remained pretty strong. Overall, $600 million sort of annualized, a pretty good run rate here, especially as we consider the sustained low rate environment. Is there any
componenttext: The first question is, can you talk a bit about statutory earnings trends? Those have remained pretty strong. Overall, $600 million sort of annualized, a pretty good run rate here, especially as we consider the sustained low rate environment. Is there any stat impact that you would expect to see as a result of low rates? Or do you think we still will see a pretty steady level of earnings power, including in the U.K.? Are you still generating the same level of, say, cash earnings that would be -- that you'd be able to take out of the U.K.? That's my first question.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rick?
componenttext: Rick?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. When you look at the stat earnings, they're actually -- the generation, we saw $150 million. That's still been a very steady run rate. So a lot can happen, but we see that very consistently even as we look to the future. Specifically to interest rat
componenttext: Sure. When you look at the stat earnings, they're actually -- the generation, we saw $150 million. That's still been a very steady run rate. So a lot can happen, but we see that very consistently even as we look to the future. Specifically to interest rates, there are impacts that can happen with lowering of discount rates on a statutory basis. But we see that baked into our results and still being able to generate that clean $150 million roughly a quarter. When you look to the U.K., I think those earnings there will come down a little bit, commensurately with what you're seeing on the GAAP side. So there will be a little bit lower earnings run rate that we see in the U.K., but nothing that we're overly concerned about. So if I took you back to a slide we were showing you in Investor Day last year, the overall capital generation of the company still is very good, and we expect that to continue.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then -- and, Rick, is there any pressure coming from the long term care business in any way, shape or form, whether it's GAAP or whether it's on statutory financials? And in what subsidiary would the long term care book or most of it be
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then -- and, Rick, is there any pressure coming from the long term care business in any way, shape or form, whether it's GAAP or whether it's on statutory financials? And in what subsidiary would the long term care book or most of it be in on a regulatory basis?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Most of our long term care book was written out of Unum America, so that's where you would see the LTC business was written. When you look at the pressure there, I don't feel any particular pressure different than we would have seen years ago at LTC. The
componenttext: Most of our long term care book was written out of Unum America, so that's where you would see the LTC business was written. When you look at the pressure there, I don't feel any particular pressure different than we would have seen years ago at LTC. The individual business, which we have stopped writing, is a more challenging business. That's why we're not writing it. And so -- but I haven’t seen the trend lines on that business change very much from what we would have seen over a number of years. So I'd say no additional pressure that we see there.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. Now, I guess, just getting back on the U.K., as we think about that business, is there any risk here of a reserve review, of anything else that we should be aware of from a margin standpoint? I mean, it sounds like it’s a challenging envir
componenttext: Got it. Okay. Now, I guess, just getting back on the U.K., as we think about that business, is there any risk here of a reserve review, of anything else that we should be aware of from a margin standpoint? I mean, it sounds like it’s a challenging environment, but is it really just an issue of looking at operating earnings? Or could there be something beyond that? Whenever I hear a situation where things are in flux and restructuring in some extent -- to some extent, that's one question that comes up. Can you address sort of that question on the U.K.?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, when you look at the U.K., I'd first start off with the margins. This business is still very high, so they were lower than we would have seen. But those were off of what we would have said, and we did say were very lofty levels. So I think you have t
componenttext: Yes, when you look at the U.K., I'd first start off with the margins. This business is still very high, so they were lower than we would have seen. But those were off of what we would have said, and we did say were very lofty levels. So I think you have to start there before we talk about the pressure. As we've seen the loss ratio creep up into the 60%, 67% range, that's even higher than we would have said a quarter ago. So there is pressure there on recognizing that, but that's more of an earnings run rate issue than anything else from a structuring perspective. And as Jack mentioned, as he looks at -- in the business and different practices he wants to bring in, hell, there will be change that goes on there, but I don't see anything material on that front.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then -- and, Jack, just one last for you. If you -- I know you talked a bit about best practices on claims handling. If you successfully overlaid your U.S. best practices on the U.K. business, are we talking about a 50-basis-point improvement
componenttext: Got it. And then -- and, Jack, just one last for you. If you -- I know you talked a bit about best practices on claims handling. If you successfully overlaid your U.S. best practices on the U.K. business, are we talking about a 50-basis-point improvement on the benefit ratio? Or 500 basis points? Can you help sort of frame what you think the opportunity there would be?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's really hard to predict what the opportunity will be. I think it's pretty clear that we can improve things through increasing the rigor of the practices and putting the appropriate resources on it. There are some differences between the U.S. a
componenttext: I think it's really hard to predict what the opportunity will be. I think it's pretty clear that we can improve things through increasing the rigor of the practices and putting the appropriate resources on it. There are some differences between the U.S. and the U.K. in terms of practices that would make it hard to predict from the U.S. experience just how much things can improve in the U.K. We -- we're very optimistic that we can make things better, but I think we'd be reluctant to put a number around what the improvement would be.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Chris Giovanni with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Chris Giovanni with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Tom, on your -- on Investor Day, you had highlighted that capital management could contribute 3% to 5% to earnings growth on a normalized basis. So if we assume the board approves another buyback authorization when the existing one is exhausted, would you
componenttext: Tom, on your -- on Investor Day, you had highlighted that capital management could contribute 3% to 5% to earnings growth on a normalized basis. So if we assume the board approves another buyback authorization when the existing one is exhausted, would you expect to see this 3% to 5% annual benefit over the next couple of years?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, you want to take that one? I think it's going to -- starts to get in the -- some of the things we'll talk about at Investor Day, actually.
componenttext: Rich, you want to take that one? I think it's going to -- starts to get in the -- some of the things we'll talk about at Investor Day, actually.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We will talk about it at Investor Day, but I think that was done -- the 3% to 5% was consistent with what we ended up doing here as we authorized our $500 million buyback. We'll obviously have to talk to our board about what we're going to do. But it all
componenttext: We will talk about it at Investor Day, but I think that was done -- the 3% to 5% was consistent with what we ended up doing here as we authorized our $500 million buyback. We'll obviously have to talk to our board about what we're going to do. But it all comes back to the earnings generation and statutory earnings and returning that to shareholders. So when you pull that all back and returning that capital and concentrating our shareholder base effectively, we'll generate those kind of earnings growth rates.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And, Chris, if I can add too, I think one of the things you can certainly sense is that we’re very confident that our business model is capable of producing much more consistent results, including statutory results. And I think Rick touched on it. When
componenttext: And, Chris, if I can add too, I think one of the things you can certainly sense is that we’re very confident that our business model is capable of producing much more consistent results, including statutory results. And I think Rick touched on it. When you have that consistent delivery of statutory results, that does take -- makes available free cash flow, that you have a lot of choices in terms of how you put that cash flow to work. To my second point, if you look at the last 3 years, we have to be one of the only companies that has been out there fairly aggressively on share buybacks as well as dividend increases, and I think that's just part of our MO going forward.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one follow-up for Kevin in terms of the group disability side at Unum US. A number of the larger competitors have people talked about -- have seen adverse loss experience and are beginning to talk about taking rate increases. Would you expe
componenttext: Okay. And then one follow-up for Kevin in terms of the group disability side at Unum US. A number of the larger competitors have people talked about -- have seen adverse loss experience and are beginning to talk about taking rate increases. Would you expect that some of these plans are shopped around and you maybe get some more looks than you've gotten in the past? Or do you think the business is just way too -- priced way too low to begin with, that even mid-single digit price increases doesn't make the risk appropriate?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t know if we'll get any more looks than we got in the past, but as the market share leader, we tend to get pretty much all the looks that are out there, and we've got the broadest field wholesale retail distribution system out there as well. But I
componenttext: I don’t know if we'll get any more looks than we got in the past, but as the market share leader, we tend to get pretty much all the looks that are out there, and we've got the broadest field wholesale retail distribution system out there as well. But I think if competitors start to raise rates in this economy, I think that would be good for stabilizing the risk environment, and I think that the quality of our field force and the diversity of our portfolio would probably -- would see some benefit from that, yes.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Mark Hughes with SunTrust.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Mark Hughes with SunTrust.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Am I right in understanding that you've been doing some consumer advertising in select markets to support the voluntary business? And if so, what kind of results have you seen from that?
componenttext: Am I right in understanding that you've been doing some consumer advertising in select markets to support the voluntary business? And if so, what kind of results have you seen from that?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question, Mark. Maybe I'll ask Kevin to state that because actually, we've been doing that mostly in Kevin's market.
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question, Mark. Maybe I'll ask Kevin to state that because actually, we've been doing that mostly in Kevin's market.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the last year or so, we've been doing some consumer advertising, primarily targeting 4 cities in the United States, trying to track changes in consumer awareness of our brand and trying to see whether the change in that awareness generates both increas
componenttext: In the last year or so, we've been doing some consumer advertising, primarily targeting 4 cities in the United States, trying to track changes in consumer awareness of our brand and trying to see whether the change in that awareness generates both increased quote activity, as well as increased maybe participation in voluntary cases. It’s still pretty early to sort of quantify whether or not those outcomes are going to be sort of the outcomes that we want. But I think early indicators are that they're helpful, that the advertising has been helpful.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then there's been some discussion about brokers maybe focusing a little more on voluntary benefits with health commission threatened to be cut. Are you seeing that?
componenttext: And then there's been some discussion about brokers maybe focusing a little more on voluntary benefits with health commission threatened to be cut. Are you seeing that?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our Simply Unum platform results allow all those brokers to integrate group and voluntary coverage, as our Simply Unum sales are very robust and up and occupy a greater and greater share of our small case market growth. And more and more brokers are
componenttext: Yes. Our Simply Unum platform results allow all those brokers to integrate group and voluntary coverage, as our Simply Unum sales are very robust and up and occupy a greater and greater share of our small case market growth. And more and more brokers are participating in the voluntary market, more and more brokers are asking for information and looking for support in that voluntary market. And we think we’re just positioned great for that.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if I could add to that, Mark, too, I think as you know, we made a pretty strong commitment a few years ago to the belief that the market was going to move more in a voluntary direction. And obviously, we've got 2 businesses in the U.S. that are benefi
componenttext: And if I could add to that, Mark, too, I think as you know, we made a pretty strong commitment a few years ago to the belief that the market was going to move more in a voluntary direction. And obviously, we've got 2 businesses in the U.S. that are beneficiaries of that. Certainly, Kevin’s business in Unum US continue to have very strong voluntary sales here this year. Randy's business, the colonials, continue to have the same. So we like the fact that we've got 2 businesses positioned to sort of capitalize on what's a very clear movement towards the voluntary business.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Ed Spehar from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Ed Spehar from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First, I wanted to go back to the U.K. and the comment that the U.K. is looking more like the U.S. but still higher margins. Can you give us some sense of where you think the U.K. ROE normalizes? And then I have one follow-up.
componenttext: Two questions. First, I wanted to go back to the U.K. and the comment that the U.K. is looking more like the U.S. but still higher margins. Can you give us some sense of where you think the U.K. ROE normalizes? And then I have one follow-up.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jack, do you want to take that question?
componenttext: Jack, do you want to take that question?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think our expectation right now, given the look at the margins and where we are, is certainly, over the long-term, we don't expect any further deterioration in the ROE. So we would peg it at that 20%, which is where it is now. With some optimism ar
componenttext: Yes. I think our expectation right now, given the look at the margins and where we are, is certainly, over the long-term, we don't expect any further deterioration in the ROE. So we would peg it at that 20%, which is where it is now. With some optimism around these pricing changes, if the market does react to that, as well as if we can get some footholds in the claim processing changes, we think there are opportunities to improve it.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: But I guess the question would be that, that doesn't sound like it looks very much like the U.S.
componenttext: But I guess the question would be that, that doesn't sound like it looks very much like the U.S.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was talking about the U.S. in terms of the erosion of margins and the level of competitiveness as opposed to the absolute level of margins. The absolute level continues to be significantly higher. It started from a much higher level than the U.S. did. I
componenttext: I was talking about the U.S. in terms of the erosion of margins and the level of competitiveness as opposed to the absolute level of margins. The absolute level continues to be significantly higher. It started from a much higher level than the U.S. did. It's a much narrower market than the U.S., so my comments were more from a relative perspective to where it had been historically, as opposed to comparing margins in the U.S. and the U.K., because they are much stronger, have always been much stronger and would expect to continue that way.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I think to add to Jack, Jack also, when he speaks, speaks to a lot of the operational efficiencies we can get by using best practices from the U.S., maybe more aggressively in the U.K., and that's also a source of value, including the fact that we’r
componenttext: And I think to add to Jack, Jack also, when he speaks, speaks to a lot of the operational efficiencies we can get by using best practices from the U.S., maybe more aggressively in the U.K., and that's also a source of value, including the fact that we’re rolling out a new offering that's very similar to Simply Unum -- as you know, we rolled out about 1.5 years ago here in the U.S. We're rolling that out in the U.K. actually here this month. So the other part of this is just the leveraging of some core capabilities that we have that are proven elsewhere and maybe more quickly accelerate the usage of those in the U.K. as well.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Look, could you remind us, if we look at the competitive dynamic in the U.K., what type of market concentration there is among the top 3 players in terms of new business?
componenttext: Look, could you remind us, if we look at the competitive dynamic in the U.K., what type of market concentration there is among the top 3 players in terms of new business?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's significantly more concentrated. There are basically 4 players in the group income protection market. There's us, Canada Life, Aviva and L&G. I think those 4 players account for some 80% of the market over here.
componenttext: It's significantly more concentrated. There are basically 4 players in the group income protection market. There's us, Canada Life, Aviva and L&G. I think those 4 players account for some 80% of the market over here.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just the question on capital for Rick. If you look at other, I would say, well-run disability companies -- I mean, take a look take at -- or group insurance companies, StanCorp talks about an RBC target of 300%. I understand
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just the question on capital for Rick. If you look at other, I would say, well-run disability companies -- I mean, take a look take at -- or group insurance companies, StanCorp talks about an RBC target of 300%. I understand your business is different; you have the U.K. piece. But I'm curious why 375% to 400% RBC plus 2x holding company requirements isn't an excessively conservative level of capital.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, when we look at the level of capital that we're holding, I think it's trying to be reflective of the environment. I think some of our peers that you mentioned are running at higher levels as well. They just haven't changed their benchmark. And I thi
componenttext: Well, when we look at the level of capital that we're holding, I think it's trying to be reflective of the environment. I think some of our peers that you mentioned are running at higher levels as well. They just haven't changed their benchmark. And I think what we're trying to say is we want to reflect the environment. So in a more difficult environment -- and I define that on a couple of fronts. One would be what we see in the economy still, which is challenging. You'd see that in unemployment and wage rolls. You can also see it in terms of the dynamic regulatory environment that we see around us. I think being a little bit more conservative makes sense. Do we need to hold there? Is that a new level that we expect the company to run at going forward? Probably not. But in today's environment, those are the levels that we think are dictated by this environment that we're in.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So -- but when you think about how you price products, so you're competing against players that are looking at lower RBC ratios, what do you still -- what do you consider as your target when you're talking to pricing actuaries and you're saying, "This is
componenttext: So -- but when you think about how you price products, so you're competing against players that are looking at lower RBC ratios, what do you still -- what do you consider as your target when you're talking to pricing actuaries and you're saying, "This is how we write business"? What's the target used for pricing formulas?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I probably won't give you the specifics on that, but it's going to be lower than we're running the company at today, for that exact reason that we're running with excess, given the environment around us. That is not our long-term expectation of the c
componenttext: Yes, I probably won't give you the specifics on that, but it's going to be lower than we're running the company at today, for that exact reason that we're running with excess, given the environment around us. That is not our long-term expectation of the capital we have. And it also is product-dependent. I won't get specific of those RBCs, but it is south of certainly where we're running the company at today.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And let's take our next question from Colin Devine with Citi.
componenttext: And let's take our next question from Colin Devine with Citi.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones. First, I guess for Jack, that sort of upward trend in the benefit ratio here in the U.K. How much longer does he think that’s going to go on? Secondly, for Kevin, I mean, you’re pretty much through the renewal season now.
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones. First, I guess for Jack, that sort of upward trend in the benefit ratio here in the U.K. How much longer does he think that’s going to go on? Secondly, for Kevin, I mean, you’re pretty much through the renewal season now. In terms of premium growth that you're looking at for next year, is it going to be fairly similar to what we've seen this year, which isn't a surprise given the economy, but just to sort of set that up? And then turning to supplemental and voluntary, in many ways on a tough quarter I guess in terms of returns, a bunch of your, I don't know if you want to call them competitors now since you're not writing individual long term care anymore, but have announced some fairly steep rate hikes over the past quarter. The interest-adjusted loss ratio there still sitting, I guess, the second highest in your company's history. Is there anything you can do to start to improve this? Are we going to be looking at this thing sitting over 80% for a while?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's go back -- thanks, Colin. Let's go back to your first question. Jack, you want to take the question about your sense of the benefit ratio in the U.K.?
componenttext: Let's go back -- thanks, Colin. Let's go back to your first question. Jack, you want to take the question about your sense of the benefit ratio in the U.K.?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, my sense of the benefit ratio is certainly, the level of deterioration in it will slow. Our premiums have begun to level out over the last couple of quarters. That’s been a factor in the benefit ratio. Depending on what happens, I think we might se
componenttext: Yes, my sense of the benefit ratio is certainly, the level of deterioration in it will slow. Our premiums have begun to level out over the last couple of quarters. That’s been a factor in the benefit ratio. Depending on what happens, I think we might see some pressure for the next couple of quarters, but I would expect, beyond that, by the second half of next year, we would have stabilized and begun to improve it.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it could get a little bit worse before it gets better. Is that fair to say?
componenttext: So it could get a little bit worse before it gets better. Is that fair to say?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think potentially, but it might not get worse before it gets better, so...
componenttext: I think potentially, but it might not get worse before it gets better, so...

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Kevin, do you want to pick up the question on renewals and premium growth and -- that question?
componenttext: Thanks, Jack. Kevin, do you want to pick up the question on renewals and premium growth and -- that question?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: 2011 renewals down versus the program. The program is slightly higher in terms of volumes than it was in 2010, and the average rate increases will be probably slightly higher, especially maybe in the core market, a little bit just reflecting the economic
componenttext: 2011 renewals down versus the program. The program is slightly higher in terms of volumes than it was in 2010, and the average rate increases will be probably slightly higher, especially maybe in the core market, a little bit just reflecting the economic environment, and -- but I think we got to be careful that -- we know that our persistency is already quite high. That's been shoring up our earned premium levels while the sales department kind of lagged. And so we're going to be careful and sort of monitor the renewal programs sort of quarter-by-quarter.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, you're on a roll. Do you want to pick up the question around the LTC strategy?
componenttext: Kevin, you're on a roll. Do you want to pick up the question around the LTC strategy?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, in group long term care, first of all, we continue to be in that market. It’s a valuable part of our portfolio, consistent with the brokers that we do voluntary benefits with. And it's very consistent with our employee benefit strategy. Much
componenttext: Yes. Well, in group long term care, first of all, we continue to be in that market. It’s a valuable part of our portfolio, consistent with the brokers that we do voluntary benefits with. And it's very consistent with our employee benefit strategy. Much of our group long term care business includes employer funding. The average age is still quite smack in the middle of the workforce in the mid-40s. That said, we have the ability to reprice group long term care because it is a group product. And we continue to evaluate sort of, over the course of time, what the right level of pricing is and how do we make sure that, that pricing matches up with the interest rate environment in particular. But in terms of operational experience, group long term care has performed quite well. On the individual side, we're no longer writing business. We’re in the process of looking at what kind of rate increase will be necessary to shore up that book of business, and we'll be rolling that through a number of discussions with state regulators over the next several weeks. And then we'll have more to report in a few weeks.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then one follow up. I didn't want to leave Randy out of this. The persistency at colonial, I think, hit record levels across the board. What's working so well for colonial that doesn't seem to be working for some of your other competitors?
componenttext: Okay, and then one follow up. I didn't want to leave Randy out of this. The persistency at colonial, I think, hit record levels across the board. What's working so well for colonial that doesn't seem to be working for some of your other competitors?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a long answer, Colin. No, we're just focused on the basics with our field force. We're really emphasizing the service side of our business and getting our agents back out to visit our inforce customers and spending time with them doing benefits cou
componenttext: That's a long answer, Colin. No, we're just focused on the basics with our field force. We're really emphasizing the service side of our business and getting our agents back out to visit our inforce customers and spending time with them doing benefits counseling. And in many cases, that doesn't add to sales. And in many others, it does, but at least gets our folks out in front of our existing customers, and we're just staying after that and having nice, steady and even improving persistency results as you pointed out. So I think it just comes back to a strong area of focus for us.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, and you are still growing sales too...
componenttext: Well, and you are still growing sales too...

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we're growing sales as well, yes.
componenttext: And we're growing sales as well, yes.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Randy Binner with FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Randy Binner with FBR Capital Markets.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was actually going to ask about colonial, too, and I guess, I think, Colin just hit on it. But your largest competitors have been having trouble really in recruiting. I guess, to see your sales are holding up and so -- I'm just wondering if there's an u
componenttext: I was actually going to ask about colonial, too, and I guess, I think, Colin just hit on it. But your largest competitors have been having trouble really in recruiting. I guess, to see your sales are holding up and so -- I'm just wondering if there's an update on kind of what sectors are working. You said public sectors was down and commercial was okay. But just understanding how that's kind of a better story for colonial versus that large competitor. And then just on a recruiting front, that seems to be going well for you as well, and the comments from the competitor have been that it's hard to recruit folks with unemployment checks persisting and salary jobs more attractive. Just kind of trying to get more color on what’s making colonial work so well.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Randy, I think you're happy to talk about that, actually. So I think we're pleased.
componenttext: Randy, I think you're happy to talk about that, actually. So I think we're pleased.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I sure am, Tom. Yes, I think the answer there is really intertwined from both sides of that. I mean, we are very focused on growing our agency distribution system. We continue to have very good results there quarter-over-quarter. We're up near 20% on
componenttext: Yes, I sure am, Tom. Yes, I think the answer there is really intertwined from both sides of that. I mean, we are very focused on growing our agency distribution system. We continue to have very good results there quarter-over-quarter. We're up near 20% on a year-to-date basis in terms of new rep contracts, and we're working very hard to make more and more of those folks productive as early as possible. And so I think it's just a matter of focus and consistency there. And that's also helping us then with our overall sales increase for the year. I mean, we're getting a considerable lift in production from reps we've brought on over the last 2 to 3 years, and that's a real difference maker for us in this very tough economic environment.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think -- I mean, so back to the recruiting issue, I mean, is that helping you recruit? Because I think that -- I guess the other folks in this area are just having trouble getting sales folks in the door. And it's -- I mean, it’s not just Aflac,
componenttext: Do you think -- I mean, so back to the recruiting issue, I mean, is that helping you recruit? Because I think that -- I guess the other folks in this area are just having trouble getting sales folks in the door. And it's -- I mean, it’s not just Aflac, but it’s other smaller franchises out there. So is it that success of new people? I'm just trying to understand it, because it seems a little bit -- it just seems like it's hard all of a sudden to get these types of sales people in the doors. Just trying to understand why the recruiting is working well.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it definitely is success breeds success, and more people wanting to come on board. And we're getting a lot of referrals for new agents from people that have joined us in the last couple of years. And it just snowballs in a very positive way f
componenttext: Yes, I think it definitely is success breeds success, and more people wanting to come on board. And we're getting a lot of referrals for new agents from people that have joined us in the last couple of years. And it just snowballs in a very positive way for us.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our last question from Jeff Schuman with KBW.
componenttext: And we'll take our last question from Jeff Schuman with KBW.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rick? Want to take that?
componenttext: Rick? Want to take that?

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. The -- it's a good lead-in actually to our Investor Day, which I'll reiterate is on November 17. But just to give you the high level, I think those flattening trends are something that you've seen from the operating earnings. It's certainly being of
componenttext: Sure. The -- it's a good lead-in actually to our Investor Day, which I'll reiterate is on November 17. But just to give you the high level, I think those flattening trends are something that you've seen from the operating earnings. It's certainly being offset by a lot of the share repurchase we've been able to do. So our EPS is growing quite nicely, and we'll give you some more insight into 2011. I think we've seen good results in 2010, consistent with the way we laid it out in the 4% to 6% range. And we'll look to 2011 and give you a similar view.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you all for taking the time to join us this morning, and I hope that we'll see you at our Investor Day meeting, which again will be in a couple of weeks. And, Ryan, this will complete our third quarter 2010 earnings call.
componenttext: Well, thank you all for taking the time to join us this morning, and I hope that we'll see you at our Investor Day meeting, which again will be in a couple of weeks. And, Ryan, this will complete our third quarter 2010 earnings call.

headline: Unum Group, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: That concludes today's conference call. We appreciate your participation.
componenttext: That concludes today's conference call. We appreciate your participation.
